* Double click on text to filter by it. (doubleclick + cmd-f for extra points).
* Click on date to keep day visible regardless of filter.

I am attempting to make a middleware to modify error messages, and am having trouble figuring out how set-descriptor!`` can be used to get access to error messages before pr-values converts them into strings. Any advice appreciated#2018-02-2700:33unwarysage#2018-02-2700:33hiredmanpr-values isn't what turns them in to strings#2018-02-2700:33unwarysage#2018-02-2700:34unwarysage@hiredman are you thinking of bencode?#2018-02-2700:34hiredmanno#2018-02-2700:34unwarysage#2018-02-2700:34hiredmaninterruptible-eval does#2018-02-2700:35hiredmanit catches exceptions when evaling and sends them back as the error nrepl message with stirng values#2018-02-2700:35hiredmanlikely the easiest thing to do would be to have your middleware watch for error nrepl messages and then eval *1 to get the error object (before pr-values)#2018-02-2700:36hiredmanpr-values only applies to the results of normal execution#2018-02-2700:36unwarysagethis is invaluable to me.#2018-02-2700:36unwarysageThank you very much#2018-02-2700:39unwarysageokay, follow up question. I have never seen a :ex keyword in a response, it's always been a string in :err#2018-02-2700:44unwarysagewhat makes :err#2018-02-2700:45hiredman:err is a message printed to *err* not an exception#2018-02-2700:46hiredman:err is like stderr#2018-02-2700:46hiredman:out is like stdout#2018-02-2700:46unwarysageokay, and I have messages coming back with :err, so and no :ex so I did not think it was that simple#2018-02-2700:48hiredmanyou can generate :errs by (binding [*out* *err*] (println "foo"))#2018-02-2700:48hiredmanand running code can do it at anytime without bubbling up an exception anywhere, or even throwing an exception#2018-02-2700:58unwarysageyes! this was exactly what I needed. expression returns nil, as expected. But if I send the buffer, I get#2018-04-2019:44unwarysageHeyo. I have a question. it seems that the view of messages in nREPL varies depending on whether I looking at them from a middleware, or from a client#2018-04-2019:45unwarysageI'm trying to write a function that takes a piece of code as a string and evaulates it, returning all nREPL messages related to it's evauluation#2018-04-2019:45unwarysageAnd for standard responses, it's fine#2018-04-2019:46unwarysageBut anything sent to err or out doesn't seem to arrive on the client side#2018-04-2019:46unwarysageWhich is unfortunate, because I am trying to write code for modifying error messages, and those don't show up#2018-04-2020:03hiredman*err* and *out* are thread local bindings, so writing to them will depend on what thread the writing to is occuring on#2018-04-2020:04hiredmanif in your server process you are spinning up some thread that somehow doesn't copy the repls values of *err* and *out* it will get the default values and nrepl won't be able to capture the output#2018-04-2020:06unwarysageSo this is what I have. 
(defn trap-response [inp-code]
(with-open [conn (repl/connect :port server-port)]
     (-> (repl/client conn 1000)
       (repl/message {:op :eval :code inp-code})
       doall)))
#2018-04-2020:06unwarysageWith some code to start an nREPL server preceding it#2018-04-2020:07unwarysageIn the middleware I am trying to test, I know that 
:err
exists#2018-04-2020:09unwarysagehow can I copy the repl values of 
*err*
?#2018-04-2020:13hiredmanit will depend on what you are running and what inp-code is doing#2018-04-2020:14hiredmane.g. a new thread launched with say future does automatically inherit the initiating threads values of err and out (also any other dynamic vars bound)#2018-04-2020:15hiredmanif you are manually creating and starting a Thread object you will have do it yourself, the easiest way is likely to use bound-fn#2018-04-2020:15unwarysagehmm#2018-04-2020:15unwarysagefor the present I am not doing anyhting threaded#2018-04-2020:15hiredmanoh, are you saying your middleware is seeing the messages with :err in them?#2018-04-2020:15unwarysageYeah#2018-04-2020:16unwarysageMy middleware is attempting to improve java error messages#2018-04-2020:16hiredmanjust somewhere between your middleware and the client the message is getting dropped#2018-04-2020:16hiredmanis your middleware forwarding on the message correctly? is it throwing an error causing the error message to be swallowed?#2018-04-2020:16unwarysageYeah, and the error message comes through, but as a print, and not in right place#2018-04-2020:17hiredmanwhat do you mean "as a print" and "not in the right place" ?#2018-04-2020:18unwarysageone moment#2018-04-2020:20unwarysageOkay, so I run trap response and I get a list of nrepl messages back#2018-04-2020:20unwarysageBut it also prints the modified error message#2018-04-2020:21unwarysageso I get something like#2018-04-2020:21unwarysage
teardown.core=> (trap-response "(banana)")
Name banana is undefined.
({:ex "class clojure.lang.Compiler$CompilerException", :id "a71b6465-6515-4b66-801c-91daa498cdf8", :root-ex "class clojure.lang.Compiler$CompilerException", :session "50e928a8-2fed-44c9-adae-8404972586f1", :status ["eval-error"]} {:id "a71b6465-6515-4b66-801c-91daa498cdf8", :session "50e928a8-2fed-44c9-adae-8404972586f1", :status ["done"]})

Eventually I hope to gain access to the exception object, but for the moment I am parsing string to string#2018-04-2020:26hiredmanare you sure you aren't just printing out the string in the middleware? it looks a lot like you are#2018-04-2020:27hiredmanI am not sure that an error like that results in anything coming back with :errr set#2018-04-2020:27hiredmanI think you just get the :ex#2018-04-2020:27unwarysageno, there are no prints in my middleware#2018-04-2020:28unwarysagemiddleware wraps the transport function in incoming messages, so that post eval this code is run#2018-04-2020:28unwarysage
(defn modify-errors "takes a nREPL response, and returns a message with the errors fixed"
  [inp-message]
  (if (contains? inp-message :err)
    (assoc inp-message :err (m-obj/get-all-text (:msg-info-obj (p-exc/process-spec-errors (inp-message :err)))))
    inp-message))
#2018-04-2020:29hiredmanI am looking at the interruptible-eval middleware right now, and when an exception is thrown it doesn't set :err, you get back the :ex message#2018-04-2020:30unwarysageand yet my middleware works. running an nrepl server with your middleware, a second running an nrepl server without your middleware, you nrepl into the second and run trap-response#2018-04-2020:41hiredman(connecting to the first)#2018-04-2020:41unwarysagewill try#2018-04-2020:42hiredmanwhere you see the message printed out will tell you if it is being printed in the client side or the server TIA.#2018-06-2706:41Timo Freiberghello, i've been looking at the stdin handling of nrepl while trying to fix CIDER issue 2317 "`(slurp in)` can't be interrupted" - https://github.com/clojure-emacs/cider/issues/2317 after fixing the part where the user couldn't stop the stream, i encountered the following issue: (slurp *in*) will close stdin after it reads EOF and then the nrepl stdin will be closed forever (or until a restart). is that something that should be changed?#2018-06-2708:03bozhidar@timo.freiberg It’s certainly a bug if we can’t use the the *in* more than once and we should fix this.#2018-06-2708:03bozhidarLuckily ever since nREPL moved out of clojure-contrib contributions have become pretty easy - https://github.com/nrepl/nrepl/#2018-06-2708:03bozhidar(the old repo is there just for legal/historical purposes - it was licensed differently to comply with clojure-contrib rules)#2018-06-2708:04bozhidarFunny enough - I eventually ended up being the maintainer of both CIDER and nREPL. 🙂#2018-06-2717:00Timo Freiberg@bozhidar yeah i noticed that after your comments this morning 🙂#2018-06-2722:33bozhidarWell, seems I was the person most motivated to get some improvements in nREPL, as CIDER is so dependent on it. 🙂 Chas didn’t have much time for the project and eventually he handed it over to me and the rest of our team.#2018-06-2821:35spiralganglionI'm hitting this error: Exception in thread "main" java.io.FileNotFoundException: Could not locate clojure/tools/nrepl__init.class or clojure/tools/nrepl.clj on classpath., compiling:(cider/piggieback.clj:1:1)#2018-06-2821:35spiralganglionI'm assuming this has to do with the recently changed namespace for nREPL — I'm using nREPL 0.4.1 and piggieback 0.3.6, building with the Clojure CLI.#2018-06-2821:37spiralganglion@bozhidar — would you kindly let me know if Piggieback still needs to be switched over to use the new nREPL ns, or if perhaps this issue is related to something else? Sounds like nREPL used to actually modify the URLClassLoader but can no longer do so?#2018-07-0105:05cflemingIf so, I’ll file a ticket for that. There’s been some discussion over in #tools-deps about this WRT their new add-lib functionality.#2018-07-0105:09cflemingThere’s also been some discussion over in #clojure-dev about it (from @razum2um)#2018-07-0105:32dominicmIn Java 8 one of the base class loader is a URL, and there was a hack to get at it. It was an implementation detail that is gone in 9. @cfleming #2018-07-0105:55cfleming@dominicm So the fix would be for nREPL to have a DCL which sits above the DCLs it creates for each eval?#2018-07-0105:56cflemingIt’s really pomegranate which doesn’t work, I guess, alembic is only broken transitively.#2018-07-0105:58dominicmExactly. I started to look at it but ran out of time. #2018-07-0121:11bozhidar@cfleming Yeah, that would be the fix IMO. I haven’t had any time to work on this either, unfortunately.#2018-07-0121:11bozhidarMost of my time went into trying to get the “new” nREPL replace the deprecated contrib one in projects like reply (done), boot (PR open) and lein (PR open).#2018-07-0121:12bozhidarI see nREPL is issuing some other warnings on Java 9/10, so the DCL might not be our only concern, so help would be welcome.#2018-07-0121:13bozhidarOn the bright side - with Clojure dropping support for Java 6 and 7, at least we can focus on support Java 8+. 🙂#2018-07-1208:09bozhidarnREPL now has an official manual http://nrepl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ It’s still pretty much a work in progress (mostly a restructuring of the old README) and your help improving it would be appreciated! What exactly are the problems you’re running into?#2018-08-0511:31pezIt is a small figwheel project that I use when hacking on Calva. I have placed all tooling dependencies in profiles.clj. {:repl {:plugins [[cider/cider-nrepl "0.18.0-SNAPSHOT"]]
        :dependencies [[nrepl "0.4.0"]
                       [cider/piggieback "0.3.5"]
                       [figwheel-sidecar "0.5.16"]]
        :repl-options {:nrepl-middleware [cider.piggieback/wrap-cljs-repl]}}}

Calva does not yet start the repls and inject stuff so people have to fiddle with these dependencies still.#2018-08-0511:48bozhidarYes, but please ignore it completely.#2018-08-0511:48pezIgnore what?#2018-08-0511:48bozhidarI created 0.19-snapshot just to experiment with nREPL 0.4.#2018-08-0511:48bozhidarEventually I just folded the work in 0.18.#2018-08-0511:49bozhidarThe version number is a bit misleading, but I needed a way to be able to distribute this to people willing to test it.#2018-08-0511:50bozhidarSee the CLI instructions here http://nrepl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/usage/#2018-08-0511:50bozhidarBasically you can just add cider-nrepl 0.18-SNAPSHOT to the example for piggieback and everything will work just fine.#2018-08-0512:07pezI am bad at ignoring things 😃 Can confirm that 0.19 didn’t crash things at startup if using the latest lein-nrepl plugin. But some Calva features stopped to work.#2018-08-0512:13pezI saw that in the lein-nrepl instructions you placed cider-nrepl in :dependencies and not in :plugins.#2018-08-0512:14bozhidarYes, that’s intentional.#2018-08-0512:14pezI am not sure what the difference is. But notice that 0-19 does not work if I keep it in :plugins, but 0.18 does.#2018-08-0512:15bozhidarThe plugin simply overwrites Lein’s repl profile config, but when you’re not using lein repl you don’t want to do this.#2018-08-0512:16bozhidarVery simply put - the plugin generates something like this section: 
:repl-options {:nrepl-middleware [cider.piggieback/wrap-cljs-repl]}}}
#2018-08-0512:16bozhidar(but populated with CIDER’s middlewares)#2018-08-0512:18bozhidar> But notice that 0-19 does not work if I keep it in :plugins, but 0.18 does.#2018-08-0512:19bozhidar0.19 doesn’t work because it generates the config, but as Lein is running an incompatible version of nREPL it can’t understand the config.#2018-08-0512:20bozhidar0.18 on the other hand checks to see if you’re running the old nREPL and uses it API if that’s the case, otherwise it switches to the new one’s API.#2018-08-0512:21bozhidarThis commit should make it clearer#2018-08-0512:21bozhidarhttps://github.com/clojure-emacs/cider-nrepl/commit/15d87747f790d300b0f13eef2e5bdc87b9dfd4ec#2018-08-0512:21pezAlso, if I move 0.18 to :dependencies the repl starts nicely, but some Calva features stop to work. They work if I keep 0.18 in :plugins.#2018-08-0512:22pez(Full profile): 
{:plugins [[nrepl/lein-nrepl "0.1.1"]]
        :dependencies [[cider/cider-nrepl "0.18.0-SNAPSHOT"]
                       [nrepl "0.4.4"]
                       [cider/piggieback "0.3.8"]
                       [figwheel-sidecar "0.5.17-SNAPSHOT"]]
        :repl-options {:nrepl-middleware [cider.piggieback/wrap-cljs-repl]}}
#2018-08-0512:22bozhidarFor 0.18 it’s fine to stay as a plugin if you’re using it with tools.nrepl.#2018-08-0512:23bozhidarAnd as lein nrepl doesn’t care about the lein repl config it won’t be affected negatively by a cider-nrepl used as a plugin, either.#2018-08-0512:24pezI’ll do that then, since that’s the config that works. Can I ask for advice about what to instruct Calva users to use? It might be a bit confusing with the above profile, since tools.nrepl will be used anyway, but it seems apt to prepare things for when it is time to move to nrepl.#2018-08-0512:30bozhidarGenerally they can just keep using lein repl like before for a while, so for now you don’t really need to change any instructions. Changes are needed only people using the cli.#2018-08-0512:32bozhidarFor users of the cli - it’s best to suggest the creation of some profile similar to the one described in nREPLs docs. Then it’s important to be careful with the versions of all deps.#2018-08-0512:33bozhidarI guess I’ll have to list somewhere a note or two about all of this. 🙂#2018-08-0823:32cflemingIn terms of making a plan to switch Cursive to nrepl.new, what do I need to bear in mind? I considered giving up on the nrepl middleware and just having the users start a sub-repl (one that has a custom :caught handler) when the client REPL connects, but unfortunately this ticket https://dev.clojure.org/jira/browse/CLJ-2040 indicates it’s not going to work#2018-09-1914:50unwarysageIt's an annoying problem.#2018-09-1914:52unwarysagethe link is good reading @bbrinck, thank you for sending it#2018-09-1914:53bbrinck@shawx538 When I get a chance, I’m going to take a crack at processing the ex-info responses as @bozhidar suggested. May I ask what you are hoping to do with them? personally, I and a team of others have been developing a translator, so that they can be understandable by beginners to programming altogether. @bbrinck#2018-09-1915:00bbrinck@shawx538 I’ve been checking in on your babel work - it’s exciting stuff 🙂. My goal is a little different - I’d like users to be able to configure their REPL experience and then share their configs. This means that I could configure a REPL designed for beginners on my team (hopefully using babel!) but perhaps swap out different tools as the users learn more#2018-09-1915:01bbrinckBasically, an extension of the proof-of-concept here: https://gist.github.com/bhb/2686b023d074ac052dbc21f12f324f18 but I’d like to make it work with nrepl clients#2018-09-1917:15dominicmhttps://github.com/jpmonettas/magic-sheet#2018-09-2720:47bozhidarIf someone’s interested in auth support for nREPL they can check out https://github.com/nrepl/nREPL/pull/46#2018-09-2805:22dominicmThinking about it, I strongly agree with you that it should be middleware. However the dependency system poses a problem for that approach. I don't have a good idea that I like though. #2018-09-2806:26bozhidar@dominicm I think if it’s just the root of all deps that should work out pretty well in practice. On server boot we can set some flag that controls the behaviour of the middleware and makes it do something or nothing. But I haven’t thought that much about this either.#2018-09-2806:32dominicm@bozhidar the root of all deps? #2018-09-2807:50bozhidar@dominicm The root of the middleware stack - every middleware would expect the auth middleware to be present.#2018-09-2807:51bozhidarGenerally that’s not really needed - I guess we’re mostly concerned about securing eval-type operations.#2018-09-2808:19dominicmThat makes sense. But conflates authentication with authorization. #2018-09-2808:20dominicmI guess the auth middleware could evaluate the request statically and determine whether it's safe. #2018-09-2808:21dominicmIs it possible to add dependencies as a user, as opposed to an author of middleware. I think that would be important. #2018-09-2813:42bozhidar> That makes sense. But conflates authentication with authorization. Yep, that’s true. Anyways, that’s why I asked for more people to share some feedback - I certainly don’t know what’s the optimum course of action, but I feel that anything will be an improvement over no security at all. 🙂#2018-09-2815:01dominicmSo, if we make this middleware, the world needs to go out and decide whether it's middleware needs to depend on auth. Conditional on being able to extend the dependencies and authorization of an op as a user, that seems fine. Separating authentication and authorization seems like a good pre emptive strike, particularly for us as we would want to inspect responses for particular values and block them under certain conditions (e.g. Breakglass)#2018-09-2816:03bozhidar> So, if we make this middleware, the world needs to go out and decide whether it’s middleware needs to depend on auth.#2018-09-2816:03bozhidarThat’s true, but the same applies for some very basic things even now - e.g. sessions.#2018-09-2816:04bozhidarOne can argue they should always be present, but since they are middleware it’s up to middleware authors to decide how to leverage them.#2018-09-2816:06bozhidar> Separating authentication and authorization seems like a good pre emptive strike, particularly for us as we would want to inspect responses for particular values and block them under certain conditions (e.g. Breakglass)#2018-09-2816:08bozhidarBtw, what when you talk about authorization you’re mostly talking about making sure people don’t execute some insecure code, right? Because if we go with a simple authentication scheme with no permissions attached to it then there won’t be much to check for when it comes to authorization.#2018-09-2816:19dominicmI would personally probably build something on a claim system that my authorization system would then check. #2018-09-2816:21bozhidarI don’t understand what you mean. Can you elaborate on this?#2018-09-2822:06dominicmYou get claims to certain functionality in production. Perhaps evaluations from a predefined set, or just refresh. That would encode into the token along with an expiration and a signature. #2018-09-2905:38bozhidarThat’d be an interesting approach indeed.#2018-10-1409:55dominicmYou know what would be cool? If you could start an nrepl the same way a socket repl is started. JVM parameters. Then you would be able to: - Easily run in production, no matter the main - Jack-in on the CLJ tools wouldn't require 2 parameters for left & right of the command line. And it wouldn't interfere with any main options the user sets. Downside: - Requires writing & compiling java (but this is a large part of nrepl already)#2018-10-1409:55dominicmI bet we can use the same technique as the socket repl does.#2018-10-1409:55dominicmIn theory it would allow you to also jack in with lein/boot. It would ignore any boot/lein settings, that might be a good thing though 😄#2018-10-1410:02dominicmI opened an issue, I think this is worth discussing https://github.com/nrepl/nREPL/issues/54#2018-10-1413:50bozhidarSure. I’ll comment there, as here the history tends to evaporate pretty quickly.#2018-10-1416:01bozhidar> - Requires writing & compiling java (but this is a large part of nrepl already)#2018-10-1416:02bozhidarI was a bit puzzled by this part, btw. nREPL uses Java a lot via interop, but it doesn’t really have any purely Java sources. 🙂 Just as an FYI; I’m not opposed to writing some good old Java for great good.#2018-10-1417:55dominicmOh really? I guess I'm misremembering. #2018-10-1418:22bozhidarReally. 🙂 There used to be some Java code back in the day, but it’s all gone now except for#2018-10-1418:23bozhidarhttps://github.com/nrepl/nREPL/blob/master/src/java/nrepl/main.java#2018-10-1418:23bozhidar(which I was planning to delete)#2018-10-1418:23bozhidar@dominicm Btw, does the manual generation work only with Node 8?#2018-10-1418:24bozhidarI’m on 10 and I get some weird errors during npm install.#2018-10-1418:24dominicmI think it does yeah. #2018-10-1418:48bozhidarOK, seems to install with 8.#2018-10-1418:48bozhidarAny idea what this error is:#2018-10-1418:48bozhidar> error: Specified start page for site not found: nrepl::index.adoc#2018-10-1418:48bozhidarHappens when I do ./antora site.yml#2018-10-1419:06dominicm@bozhidar try adding master to the list of branches, or is it there already? #2018-10-1422:07bozhidarYeah, that worked.#2018-10-1422:08bozhidarI wonder why master doesn’t show in the drop down version though.#2018-10-1422:08bozhidarI’ve seen in the demos that both tags and branches should appear there, but maybe I just don’t understand it well enough so far.#2018-10-1422:08bozhidarAt any rate - I managed to generate something. 🙂#2018-10-1505:51dominicm@bozhidar the version is in a yml file in the nrepl repo#2018-10-1508:59bozhidar@dominicm I’m puzzled. What’s the purpose of that config file? It seems to duplicate some of the info in the site.yml. I guess assumed that running antora would generate the docs for all non-blacklisted tags (meaning no tags currently) + the master branch.#2018-10-1508:59bozhidar(as I added it to site.yml)#2018-10-1509:01dominicm@bozhidar it's a little confusing in the case you have 1 to 1 mapping. Antora allows you to build multiple repos into one site. One example would be for Asciidoctor, they bundle asciidoctor, asciidoctorJ, asciidoctor.js, etc. into one site. All as part of the Asciidoctor organization. Each of those site "sections" has their own antora.yml, which details information about the component. e.g. version, name, title.#2018-10-1509:02dominicmhttps://docs.antora.org/antora/1.1/component-structure/ might be useful.#2018-10-1509:06bozhidarYeah, I got this part, but I thought the config we had in the site.yml pertained to the only component we have. 🙂#2018-10-1509:07bozhidarIn general I can how useful this component structure would be if we decide to put in the manual also something about piggieback, drawbridge, cider-nrepl, refactor-nrepl, etc.#2018-10-1509:07dominicmBingo.#2018-10-1509:07dominicmAnd very cool is how there's a xref system in place for safely referencing across components.#2018-10-1509:08dominicmhttps://docs.antora.org/antora/1.0/asciidoc/page-to-page-xref/#2018-10-1509:10dominicmI want to try and get cljdoc to support the xref: macro, because it would allow for some really neat things like: 
Takes a xref:bidi::vhosts.adoc#model[Bidi VHosts Model] and returns a Yada Handler which processes Yada Resources inside.
#2018-10-1509:10dominicmWhere bidi is just another project on cljdoc.#2018-10-1509:20bozhidarYeah, that’s pretty cool indeed.#2018-10-1607:37bozhidar@dominicm So, what’s your idea about loading nREPL early on? Just adding some class with static initializer perhaps?#2018-10-1607:37dominicm@bozhidar I tried that, it didn't work 😞 I didn't realise that Clojure is able to do this because everyone is running clojure, so clojure.lang.RT is pretty much always loaded.#2018-10-1607:40bozhidarI’m out of ideas then, but I’m certain you’ll think of something. I got pretty excited when you proposed this, so I hope we can make it work somehow.#2018-10-1607:40bozhidarIdeally without having to use a patched version of Clojure. 😄#2018-10-1608:00dominicmthe compromise might be that a user has to do (import nrepl.server) somewhere in their codebase. But that isn't wonderful for loading ourselves into java programs.#2018-10-2317:13dotemacsI remember reading that http://nrepl.org domain was purchased: https://github.com/nrepl/nrepl/issues/31 which now points to https://nrepl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ But I also see that http://nrepl.xyz exists and redirects to: https://nrepl.xyz/nrepl/0.4.5/index.html which I’m guessing is the automated documentation generated by http://cljdoc.org (which used to be http://cljdoc.xyz) I was about to ask which URL will be used, but seeing the GitHub project page, https://nrepl.xyz is mentioned. So that mystery is solved. Looking at https://cljdoc.org/d/nrepl/nrepl/0.4.5/doc/readme and https://nrepl.xyz/nrepl/0.4.5/index.html the pages have a different style. Is this just the way cljdoc service is meant to work? One uniform style for all the projects sitting under http://cljdoc.org domain and another style if the documentation is accessed via the custom domain of the project?#2018-10-2317:38dominicm@dotemacs the self hosted documentation is just antora.#2018-10-2317:46bozhidar> One uniform style for all the projects sitting under http://cljdoc.org domain and another style if the documentation is accessed via the custom domain of the project?#2018-10-2317:46bozhidarhttp://nrepl.org was purchased by @arrdem, but he was busy lately and I got another domain to make it easier for me to play with Antora.#2018-10-2317:47bozhidarI hope we’ll use it at some point, but the old RTD docs are dead and http://nrepl.xyz is the single source of truth.#2018-10-2317:48bozhidarWe’ll likely link to all the pages in http://cljdoc.org as well, but it’s lower priority compared to actually writing some goods docs.#2018-10-2317:48bozhidarI’ve spent a lot of time lately extending what’s on http://nrepl.xyz.#2018-10-2317:50bozhidarWe also need to cut a new release for the http://cljdoc.org stuff to be get regenerated.#2018-10-2318:08dotemacsThank you both for the answer.#2018-10-2913:28bozhidarhttps://metaredux.com/posts/2018/10/29/nrepl-redux.html#2018-10-2914:17eraserhdHey, this reminds me. I have a need for an nREPL client that is thin and super light-weight, for CLI use. Well, not exactly for CLI use, but for use by an editor that is heavily bought into the idea of small tools and UNIX. Which means, I think, that the client needs to maintain persistent connection, by forking and forwarding.#2018-10-2914:18eraserhdI started hacking on a tool a few weeks ago (called rep, because it doesn't l). I added the Drawbridge Ring handler into my web app and tried to connect to it like this: 
(require '[nrepl.core :as nrepl]
           '[drawbridge.client :as client])

(with-open [conn (nrepl/url-connect "")]
    (-> (nrepl/client conn 1000)
        (nrepl/message {:op "eval" :code "(+ 2 3)"})
        nrepl/response-values))
But I get this error: ArityException Wrong number of args (0) passed to: client/ring-client-transport/read--2318 clojure.lang.AFn.throwArity (AFn.java:429)#2018-10-3012:01flowthingIt looks like the read function in the Drawbridge client expects a single argument (https://github.com/nrepl/drawbridge/blob/941403588c1cde61f8041f4de82ed53bea837590/src/drawbridge/client.clj#L50) but the calling code in nrepl.transport doesn't supply any https://github.com/nrepl/nrepl/blob/ff70f1e4cac4ee72cdaba1d95f1216640c84e572/src/clojure/nrepl/transport.clj#L41).#2018-10-3012:02flowthingI can't see how that'd work, but maybe I'm missing something. That’s something that can easily be added to lein nrepl. It is time to fix that, and maybe I should before investigating the problems it has with 0.4.5.#2018-11-1917:50bozhidarNo idea. (ns routing-example.user
  (:use [figwheel-sidecar.repl-api :as ra]))

(defn start []
  (ra/start-figwheel!)
  (ra/cljs-repl "dev"))

(defn stop []
  (ra/stop-figwheel!))
#2018-11-2016:21bozhidarI’ll have to check figwheel-sidecar deps then. Likely it’s pulling the wrong version of nREPL.#2018-11-2016:22bozhidarhttps://github.com/bhauman/lein-figwheel/blob/master/sidecar/project.clj#L31#2018-11-2016:23bozhidarYep, that’s messing everything up. If you remove this file all will be good.#2018-11-2016:23bozhidarThis loads tools.nrepl, which makes cider-nrepl believe you’re using tools.nrepl (as it checks if it’s loaded to decide which nREPL version to use).#2018-11-2016:24bozhidarI’m pretty sure everything will work fine for you without this file.#2018-11-2106:19pezYou mean remove that dependency in my local sidecar?#2018-11-2109:13bozhidarI mean - try to run things without user.clj and running that code after you’ve connected.#2018-11-2114:35pezHaha. Sorry. 😃#2018-11-2208:01pez@bozhidar, OK. So now I got the time to try this again. If I remove the dependency on sidecar all together, things that used to work, still work (in Calva). Except anything ClojureScript, of course. Is Cider working with ClojureScript using the new nrepl?#2018-11-2208:34bozhidar@pez Of course. 🙂#2018-11-2208:34bozhidarThe problem is not nREPL - the problem is the dependency loading got messed up in your case and you’re running one version of the server and middleware that expects the other one.#2018-11-2208:35bozhidarThat comes from this code.#2018-11-2208:36bozhidarhttps://github.com/clojure-emacs/cider-nrepl/blob/master/src/cider/nrepl.clj#L8#2018-11-2208:37bozhidarI hope that this makes sense. With user.clj your altering the expected load order of the libraries, so and in your case it seems to me that sidecar loads the legacy tools.nrepl at some point even though you’re actually trying to connect to the new one.#2018-11-2208:38bozhidarThat’s going to be fixed for good when I completely kill the support for tools.nrepl in a release or two. But for now without a lein release in a long time it was necessary.#2018-11-2208:42pezI think I have understood that the problem is not nREPL. 😄 But even without user.clj I get that trace as long as I have a dependency on sidecar. And without sidecar I don’t know how to start the cljs repl (for Figwheel projects).#2018-11-2208:44dominicmIt's to do with lazy Loading @bozhidar #2018-11-2208:44dominicmBecause we lazily load middleware, it finds a different nrepl at different points#2018-11-2208:45bozhidar@dominicm Yeah, but this can only happen if some dep explicitly requires tools.nrepl in the mean time, which should not happen most of the time.#2018-11-2208:45dominicmWhy shouldn't it? #2018-11-2208:46bozhidarBecause I assume that most libraries will follow the same pattern as us - have a hard dep on nrepl and dynamically select tools.nrepl if it happens to be present. At least that’s what all the libs I’m involved with do.#2018-11-2208:48pezSo, I should file a PR on sidecar doing that?#2018-11-2208:49pezI’m still puzzled how you get the cljs repl up without sidecar, @bozhidar#2018-11-2208:49bozhidar@pez It’s all about the load order - if you load all middleware first this is going to work just fine.#2018-11-2208:50bozhidarAs you can see sidecar has support for the new nREPL https://github.com/bhauman/lein-figwheel/blob/dfd010d372280746f64397328fb9a402d448276d/sidecar/src/figwheel_sidecar/components/nrepl_server.clj#L6#2018-11-2208:51bozhidarhttps://github.com/bhauman/lein-figwheel/blob/dfd010d372280746f64397328fb9a402d448276d/sidecar/src/figwheel_sidecar/repl.clj#L228#2018-11-2208:52pezRight, so no PR needed. 😃#2018-11-2208:52bozhidarWhen I tested this it worked just fine for me.#2018-11-2208:53pezI don’t know how to configure the load order, I guess.#2018-11-2208:53bozhidarProbably just changing the dependency that sidecar has is going to fix this, but I don’t have time to look into this. You can update project.clj, build it locally and try.#2018-11-2208:53bozhidarIf no other lib you use has a dep on tools.nrepl then this must the root cause of the problem.#2018-11-2208:53pezOK, I’ll do that right away.#2018-11-2208:55pezBut it still seems strange that I need a patched sidecar, when you don’t. There is something important I am not getting here.#2018-11-2209:00bozhidarI’m not using user.clj.#2018-11-2209:00pezMe neither.#2018-11-2209:00bozhidarI just start figwheel via cider-jack-in and that’s it.#2018-11-2209:00bozhidarBut I also have no other deps. Badly.#2018-11-2209:17bozhidarI assume it’s going to be pretty easy for you to just carbon-copy CIDER’s approach, as there’s nothing specific about it.#2018-11-2209:18bozhidarWe just build a command string that will start nREPL + the necessary middleware, run it and parse its output to check when the server has started.#2018-11-2209:18bozhidarThen we open a connection the server - business as usual.#2018-11-2209:27pezYes, I think the trickiest part will be how to know when I can connect.#2018-11-2209:30pezOK. So if I remove that dependency from sidecar’s projectclj and move piggieback up before nrepl in :dependencies, then it works. I can even have my user.clj and use that for starting the cljs repl.#2018-11-2209:54bozhidarWe’re making progress. 🙂#2018-11-2210:16pezFor some misconfigurations, sidecar (I think) gives some hints about piggieback and adds:

This can cause confusion when your are not using Cider.

Any tips? 🙏#2018-12-0410:55bozhidar@holyjak Generally the clients are supposed to provide the greeting message. TTY is an exception as there if you don’t send something server-side you won’t even realize you’ve connected.#2018-12-0410:56bozhidarIf you elaborate on what you’re trying to achieve I might be able to give you some alternative idea.#2018-12-0411:02bozhidarBtw, I’m puzzled that the greeting fn approach didn’t work for you - it’s a very generic way of sending some message(s) on connect. This should be just fine regardless of your transport.#2018-12-0412:03Jakub Holý (HolyJak)Thanks @bozhidar! I have a legacy java/groovy app and want to start a nrepl server within the app so that I could explore it while it is running. I'm not sure if lein-nrepl (https://github.com/nrepl/lein-nrepl) can be configured to work.#2018-12-0420:03dominicmhttps://github.com/nrepl/lein-nrepl#using-with-cider 
(setq cider-inject-dependencies-at-jack-in nil)
(setq lein-parameters "nrepl")
Apparently 🙂#2018-12-0420:09dchelimskyThanks for the help @dominicm. Unfortunately, I now have 
:repl {:dependencies [[nrepl/nrepl "0.5.1"]]
        :plugins      [[cider/cider-nrepl "0.18.0"]
                       [nrepl/lein-nrepl "0.3.1"
                        :exclusions [org.clojure/clojure
                                     nrepl
                                     commons-io
                                     commons-codec]]]}
in profiles.clj and 
(setq cider-inject-dependencies-at-jack-in nil)
(setq lein-parameters "nrepl")
in init.el and I still get nREPL 0.2.12#2018-12-0420:14dominicm@dchelimsky When jack-in runs, can you see whether it runs lein repl or lein nrepl?#2018-12-0420:15dchelimskyrepl#2018-12-0420:15dchelimskyWhich suggests that (setq lein-parameters "nrepl") isn't being read#2018-12-0420:16dominicmI'm not an emacs/cider user, so I'm not much help here I'm afraid. M-x customize-var might be able to tell you the proper variable name though.#2018-12-0420:17dchelimskyJust trying that#2018-12-0420:17dchelimskyOh, weird. Now I get "'nrepl' is not a task". Progress!#2018-12-0420:20dominicm@dchelimsky I think your problem is that you've put the lein-nrepl plugin inside of the :repl profile. Maybe it should be the :user profile? I guess :repl is only loaded for lein repl?#2018-12-0420:28dchelimskyYes, that makes sense. Now, of course, I'm getting dependency conflicts that are apparently not-resolvable. :pedantic? :abort is telling me to exclude something but when I exclude it I still get the same message.#2018-12-0420:30dominicm@dchelimsky Exclusions added to plugins are ignored. It's an counter-intuitive quirk of leiningen. The trick is to add a dependency on lein-nrepl with the exclusions, as well as having the :plugins for it.#2018-12-0420:32dchelimsky"as well as having the :plugins for it." meaning also include lein-nrepl in plugins, but without the exclusions?#2018-12-0420:33dominicm@dchelimsky correct 🙂#2018-12-0420:42dchelimskyI still get the messages if I leave out the exclusions from :plugins#2018-12-0420:42dominicm@dchelimsky did you move them to :dependencies?#2018-12-0420:43dchelimsky
:user {:dependencies [[nrepl/nrepl "0.5.1"]
                       [nrepl/lein-nrepl "0.3.1"
                        :exclusions [org.clojure/clojure
                                     nrepl
                                     commons-io
                                     commons-codec]]]
        :plugins      [[cider/cider-nrepl "0.18.0"]
                       [nrepl/lein-nrepl "0.3.1"
                        :exclusions [org.clojure/clojure
                                     nrepl
                                     commons-io
                                     commons-codec]]]

I'm sure it would have anyway, but raising it as an explicit thing. #2018-12-0821:22bozhidarThere’s nothing special about transports - I assume we’d be side-loading them just as any other library.#2018-12-0822:00dominicmDepends how early the side loader is available#2018-12-1011:12cgrandYou can inject any transport as long as it’s based on a stream of characters#2018-12-1011:14cgrandso drawbridge is out (what’s the point of injecting a HTTP transport over an SSH tunneled socket repl)#2018-12-1011:15cgrandbinary transports are out too (ok maybe with a good amount of reflection it may be worked out)#2018-12-1015:45cgrandIs *msg* dead code or something used for debug?#2018-12-1016:40bozhidar@cgrand I think without it being bound responses don’t have ids.#2018-12-1016:41bozhidarWhat lead you to believe it might be dead code?#2018-12-1016:42cgrandI didn’t look into session for it 😕 (I really thought I did search the whole codebase)#2018-12-1016:43cgrandnow I feel less bad about creating a circular dep between session and interruptible-eval#2018-12-1016:48cgrandSo thread management should move to session (where clone and close are handled)#2018-12-1019:02bozhidarAs *msg* is just an implementation detail perhaps you can also find a different way to track the active message.#2018-12-1019:02bozhidarI don’t think that any user code depends on this.#2018-12-1019:04bozhidarBut moving thread management to sessions is also reasonable. The only tricky part will be retaining the thread-local bindings between threads.#2018-12-1020:33cgrand@bozhidar Bindings of dynvars or of ThreadLocals? I don’t know if you’ve read my latest proposal on #16: a thread per session with a caveat emptor about interrupting evaluation. #2018-12-1020:36cgrandBtw in addition to interrupt in unrepl we have the ability to background the current eval (it returns immediately as a future). #2018-12-1021:12bozhidar> a thread per session with a caveat emptor about interrupting evaluation.#2018-12-1021:13bozhidarYeah, that makes a lot of sense. And solves the problem I was thinking about - namely preserving the dynvar bindings, as those are stored in the session anyways.#2018-12-1021:14bozhidar> Btw in addition to interrupt in unrepl we have the ability to background the current eval (it returns immediately as a future).#2018-12-1021:15bozhidarI guess that something like this might be useful to some people who want to enqueue a few long-running evaluations, but I’m not certain how common this scenario is.#2018-12-1117:27cgrand@bozhidar have a look at https://github.com/nrepl/nrepl/commit/61e23d8b3a8a01f7fcbcc7175e9f710e61cddc89#2018-12-1210:18bozhidar@cgrand Looks good to me. The only thing that’s a bit of a problem is that moving the default executor will break cider-nrepl, as there was a bit of code using this implementation detail directly, but that’s not a big deal.#2018-12-1210:19bozhidarI guess it would also be nice to document the new behavior accordingly, although that’d be mostly for us - I highly doubt that anyone relied on the implementation details of the execution.#2018-12-1210:39cgrandin the doc for :interrupt?#2018-12-1210:19bozhidarOne more somewhat related thing is the handling of output that we discussed could be improved if we have one thread per session, but I guess this can be done later.#2018-12-1210:22bozhidar@dchelimsky The new Lein 2.8.2 is out! 🙂#2018-12-1212:08dchelimskyThanks for letting me know!#2018-12-1210:25cgrand@bozhidar another breaking change is that the configurable excutor to interruptible-eval is ignored — is it used in practice?#2018-12-1210:25cgrandand what do you do in cider-nreplwith the executor?#2018-12-1210:27cgrandOh, that’s only for tests?#2018-12-1210:32cgrandHaving worked on thread management, I’m now wondering if I missed a documentation on the execution model (not the implementation). My understanding: • msgs from different session are concurrent • :eval msgs for a given session are serialized • non-`:eval` msgs for a given session are... concurrent?#2018-12-1210:38bozhidar> @bozhidar another breaking change is that the configurable excutor to interruptible-eval is ignored — is it used in practice?#2018-12-1210:38bozhidarIt’s not.#2018-12-1210:39cgrandin the doc for :interrupt?#2018-12-1210:39bozhidar> and what do you do in cider-nreplwith the executor?#2018-12-1210:39bozhidarIt’s used directly in the test-runner - https://github.com/clojure-emacs/cider-nrepl/blob/7d2ed83b3a57f3883f4a9edd7f6cf83a8d0888b0/src/cider/nrepl/middleware/test.clj#L358#2018-12-1210:39bozhidarI think that’d be an easy change, so I’m not worried about this.#2018-12-1210:40bozhidar> Having worked on thread management, I’m now wondering if I missed a documentation on the execution model (not the implementation).#2018-12-1210:40bozhidarYour understanding is perfect.#2018-12-1210:41bozhidarI guess we never really documented this, so it’s now only an urban legend. 🙂#2018-12-1210:43cgrandThe spooky kind: passed amongst client implementors around campfires...#2018-12-1210:44bozhidar😄#2018-12-1210:45cgrandOh and one can’t interrupt a stray eval (an eval on a transient session) anymore#2018-12-1210:46bozhidarThe difference between the behavior of eval and non-eval messages was a big argument in favour of moving most of the client functionality to middlewares, as if they constantly evaled some messages to get things like completion candidates that could impact performance negatively.#2018-12-1210:46bozhidarWhat’s a transient session?#2018-12-1210:50cgrandtransient session: non-cloned one#2018-12-1210:53cgrandexecution model: thanks for the background; what about serializing execution on session+op? (I don’t have an actual plan, just questioning the statu quo)#2018-12-1211:03cgrandThis will need to be reworked https://github.com/clojure-emacs/cider-nrepl/blob/7d2ed83b3a57f3883f4a9edd7f6cf83a8d0888b0/src/cider/nrepl/middleware/test.clj#L274-L287#2018-12-1211:09bozhidar> execution model: thanks for the background; what about serializing execution on session+op? (I don’t have an actual plan, just questioning the statu quo)#2018-12-1211:11bozhidarI guess it depends on the op - most ops don’t really affect the global state, so it’s fine to run them concurrently. I don’t see a need for serializing individual ops, unless something in the implementation of the op requires it - e.g. I can imagine multiple refresh ops running in parallel might be a bad idea, but I also wonder if that’s something people encounter in practice.#2018-12-1211:12bozhidarPerhaps there could be some flag to force ops to be serialized to make sure they’re safely applied?#2018-12-1211:12bozhidar> transient session: non-cloned one#2018-12-1211:13bozhidarAh, got it. I’ve been wondering from time to time if we should allow the usage of non-cloned sessions at all. I don’t really see any value in them, but I might be missing something.#2018-12-1211:14bozhidar> This will need to be reworked https://github.com/clojure-emacs/cider-nrepl/blob/7d2ed83b3a57f3883f4a9edd7f6cf83a8d0888b0/src/cider/nrepl/middleware/test.clj#L274-L287#2018-12-1211:14bozhidarYep. Not a big deal, though.#2018-12-1211:15cgrandI’ve created a PR for #16 https://github.com/nrepl/nrepl/pull/98#2018-12-1212:08dchelimskyThanks for letting me know!#2018-12-1212:09bozhidar@cgrand Thanks! I’ll take a look!#2018-12-1309:12bozhidar@cgrand I left a bit of feedback on the PR, but overall it looks great. Fantastic work!#2018-12-1410:07cgrandReading #44 (https://github.com/nrepl/nrepl/issues/44) caused me to create #100.#2018-12-1410:07cgrandhttps://github.com/nrepl/nrepl/issues/100#2018-12-1412:09cgrandAnd here is the PR https://github.com/nrepl/nrepl/pull/101#2018-12-1607:32cfleming@cgrand Great to see all the work you’re doing on nREPL. I’m curious, how has your thinking about streaming vs RPC-style REPLs developed after working on unrepl and now nREPL?#2018-12-1607:33cflemingI remember at one point you mentioned that you thought you understood Rich’s philosophy on REPLs better after working on unrepl, and I’m pretty sure Rich wouldn’t classify nREPL as a REPL.#2018-12-1709:26cgrandAs I was reading Drawbridge, I stumbled on: 
(if (find-ns 'clojure.tools.nrepl)
  (require
   '[clojure.tools.nrepl :as nrepl]
   '[clojure.tools.nrepl.server :as server]
   '[clojure.tools.nrepl.transport :as transport])
  (require
   '[nrepl.core :as nrepl]
   '[nrepl.server :as server]
   '[nrepl.transport :as transport]))
Wouldn’t it be more sensible to prefer nrepl.core over clojure.tools.nrepl?#2018-12-1709:40cgrand@cfleming putting my thoughts together would take time and a small article. streaming pros: super simple model: 1 connection :: 1 repl :: 1 thread; can be taken over (powerful) streaming cons: tracking progress (see prepl and unrepl takes), mixed output streams (because of laziness, modern envs with more than 1 thread, err vs out etc.) (again unrepl and prepl both frame outputs, so their output is a stream of forms instead of a stream of characters); can be taken over (interfer with framing) RPC pros: 1 connection for everything; easy progress report (because framed input) RPC cons: thread management/serialization of evals; explicit lifecycle management; can not be taken over#2018-12-1709:46cgrandsummary reality is complex, RPC and streaming are ends of a continuum#2018-12-1710:01bozhidarExcellent summary!#2018-12-1710:01bozhidar> Wouldn’t it be more sensible to prefer nrepl.core over clojure.tools.nrepl?#2018-12-1710:03bozhidar@cgrand Probably. I didn’t think much about this, as it was supposed to be a temporary measure and now that leiningen ships nREPL 0.5 we can remove all the compatibility code.#2018-12-1710:04bozhidarProbably I’ll cut one more release of cider-nrepl that supports tools.nrepl and afterwards I’ll go over all the middleware/transport projects and drop this for simplicity’s sake.#2018-12-1711:54cgrandI’m happy to report that datafy/nav is now supported by rich (unrepl) printing: https://github.com/nrepl/nrepl/commit/26e51fbca0dfba5a9ee247605445df7e58e83269#2018-12-1712:29cgrandObviously (as for elisions) it requires client-side ui. A datafiable value is represented as #unrepl/browsable [plain-value browsable-value] and to make this lazy the browsable-value is elided. For nav, it’s the same thing: if the datafied value is a map or a vector and is navigable then the map values becomes elided #unrepl/browsable whose elision triggers nav.#2018-12-1712:30dominicmDoes this affect existing clients? How? #2018-12-1712:32cgrandunrepl printing is opt-in (set :printer to nrepl.elisions/printer on :eval)#2018-12-1714:31eraserhd@cgrand I've been playing with the idea of not needing client side UI by binding variables to ..1 ..2 ..3 and so forth. Except I can't quite make the idea work.#2018-12-1714:34cgrandfor some simple elisions, it sort of work#2018-12-1714:34cgrandI experimented with /1 /2 etc.#2018-12-1714:35cgrandthey are not readable so won’t clash with clojure code#2018-12-1714:36cgrand..x are going to be tranformed by the compiler I think (because of the leading dot)#2018-12-1714:36eraserhdAhh, I wasn't to worried about that. I was worried about needing to keep the numbers forever.#2018-12-1714:36cgrand(if they ccur in function position)#2018-12-1714:37cgrandindeed if you use vars, they are interned and you can’t knwo when to GC#2018-12-1714:37eraserhdyou are right, hrmm#2018-12-1714:38eraserhd(re: .)#2018-12-1714:38cgrandor you can choose to keep the last N vars#2018-12-1714:39eraserhdright, and then you have unusable stuff in your history.#2018-12-1714:39eraserhdbut, I want it to work! :D#2018-12-1714:39cgrandat some point GC pressure may cause collection of elisions anyway#2018-12-1714:40cgrandclick (or tab-navigate) to expand is a better ux if you can afford to#2018-12-1714:41cgrandwith datafy/nav, many values may be littered with small affordances hinting that an alternate view is available#2018-12-1714:44eraserhdAnyway, I'm super excited to have this somehow baked in to my REPL. It solves quite a few problems for me, including 10,000 line exceptions in my primary app. So, thanks for working on it!#2018-12-1717:02eraserhdHey, that brings up a question about the nREPL client API. Why have a split between connection and client? It doesn't seem like multiple clients are possible per connection.#2018-12-1718:05dominicmThey are. #2018-12-1718:05dominicmWhy do you think they aren't? #2018-12-1719:21cfleming@cgrand Thanks! I agree that the main benefit of streaming REPLs is that they’re composable, but that definitely comes at a cost.#2018-12-1719:23cgrand@cfleming no they are not; see https://github.com/nrepl/nrepl/issues/45#issuecomment-444476311#2018-12-1719:24eraserhd@dominicm I meant, to be clear, that it doesn't seem to add anything, AFAICT. There's not concept of client on the wire protocol, only session. And that's another layer of abstraction in the API.#2018-12-1719:25dominicm@eraserhd I don't understand the point you're making. Can you give an example? #2018-12-1719:27eraserhdI don't have a point, I want to understand abstracting clients from connections and sessions.#2018-12-1719:27dominicm@eraserhd what's a client in this context? #2018-12-1719:28eraserhdreturn of nrepl.core/client #2018-12-1719:29eraserhdhttps://nrepl.org/nrepl/usage/clients.html#_talking_to_an_nrepl_endpoint_programmatically #2018-12-1719:35dominicmBut you would call that from a separate process, not necessarily even the same network#2018-12-1815:53cgrandI’m trying to come up with a typology of eval messages, so far I identified four kinds: 1/ regular repl 2/ eval selection (in file buffer) and update repl (`*1` and friends are impacted), serialized with evals of type #1; switch and restore ns as required 3/ eval selection (in file buffer) but displays output in a transient buffer, not serialized with type #1, doesn’t update bindings 4/ out-of-the-blue eval for tooling purposes (doesn’t change bindings)#2018-12-1815:55cgrand#4 and #3 may be the same#2018-12-1816:04eraserhdmaybe interprocess remote control?#2018-12-1816:11cgrandhat do you mean?#2018-12-1816:13eraserhdNot sure the purpose of the typology, but one use I've overheard is processes talking to each other. There's a bit in the nREPL about using the protocol to notify another server that it's alive and on what port, for example.#2018-12-1816:14eraserhdI can't delete my DynamoDBs which back my Datomic databases from my laptop, so my restore-dev-environment-from-prod-back script runs datomic.api/delete-database via the socket REPL (over SSH).#2018-12-1816:15eraserhdIs this tooling for purposes of your typology?#2018-12-1817:45cgrandyes becaue it’s not tied to a user session (a user session being embodied by a repl buffer with history etc.)#2018-12-1816:04eraserhdAlso might be just #4#2018-12-1816:06eraserhdhey, so it's pretty featureless and not yet documented, but rep, a single-shot nREPL client, is here: https://github.com/eraserhd/rep/tree/develop#2018-12-1816:07eraserhdBuilding with Graal will be documented. It's painful and requires a patched Clojure and patched spec.alpha.#2018-12-1816:11cgrandhat do you mean?#2018-12-1817:51cgrandRendering is half broken but remote browsing in action#2018-12-1818:05eraserhd\o/#2018-12-1916:25cgrandGuys, bencode is byte-based but in the transport we assume all byte arrays in messages to be UTF8 strings. There’s no easy way to use raw binary without adding much complexity. Base64 to the rescue. Right?#2018-12-2003:11cfleming@cgrand I meant that pure streaming REPLs are composable, but limited.#2018-12-2005:40cgrand@cfleming it’s with the composability that I strongly disagree. When repls are nested their powers don’t compose because only the innermost is running. #2018-12-2006:13cgrand@cfleming imagine you have two repls: one which uses pprint and the other with a slightly more informative prompt. There’s no way to get both features at the same time. #2018-12-2006:38cfleming@cgrand Yes, I agree - compose is the wrong word. I’m really talking about them being nestable.#2018-12-2015:15cgrandSideloading (loading resources/classes from the client without shared filesystem) in nrepl works: https://github.com/nrepl/nrepl/blob/0cfa805ce7f249c5fd9da4bb5343f3130bbc5784/test/clojure/nrepl/core_test.clj#L608-L613#2018-12-2015:29dominicmThis implementation doesn't allow for transports to be sideloaded. Unless we add support for nesting perhaps. #2018-12-2015:56cgrandWhy would you want to change transport?#2018-12-2016:11cgrandSwitch encoding over same connection or install a new connection?#2018-12-2016:53cgrand@dominicm could you describe the scenario you have in mind?#2018-12-2017:16dominicm@cgrand now you have made the logistics clear, I think same connection is better for firewall reasons. My reasoning is that editors currently have to specify the transport the user chooses ahead of time in the server, eg vim might choose a json transport, but Emacs uses edn. Perhaps it would be useful for clients to bring a transport, and upgrade a standard connection somehow.#2018-12-2017:26cgrandWhat are the connection means in use today? TCP socket, stdin/stdout and drawbridge?#2018-12-2017:29cgrandAn injectable nREPL over plain repl would cover the first two cases. Then maybe we would need a drawbridge-lite#2018-12-2017:57dominicmIn practice? Bencode only,#2018-12-2017:58dominicmPretty much anyway afaik. #2018-12-2018:11pezYes, bencode, but I'd like to switch over to EDN for Calva. I guess most Calva users are in control over the server. #2018-12-2018:23cgrandNo drawbridge in practice?#2018-12-2018:25dominicmI hear someone trying it occasionally, but not really#2018-12-2020:47cgrandDoes anybody know of a middleware which uses raw binary (byte arrays)? It seems unlikely given my understanding of the whole stack but I prefer to ask.#2018-12-2112:01bozhidar@cgrand I’m back behind a keyboard, so I’ll catch up with the messages and the PRs soon.#2018-12-2112:02bozhidar> Does anybody know of a middleware which uses raw binary (byte arrays)? It seems unlikely given my understanding of the whole stack but I prefer to ask.#2018-12-2112:02bozhidarI don’t think so. I have to check what exactly was the content-type middleware doing, but everything else certainly deals only with data that’s representable as text.#2018-12-2113:30cgrandI already checked: base64, not raw binary#2018-12-2115:05bozhidarGreat. I guess we can just mention somewhere that people can’t use binary data. Potentially we can also enforce this somewhere just to be on the safe side. At any rate - I’m certainly not concerned about making it clear people are not supposed to use middleware in this manner.#2018-12-2113:30cgrandI already checked: base64, not raw binary#2018-12-2116:14bozhidar@cgrand @dominicm When you’ve got some time can you take a look here and share your thoughts on the message logging approach?#2018-12-2116:15bozhidarThis PR has been dragging on for a while and before we wrap it up I’m curious to hear what you think about it.#2018-12-2116:44pez@bozhidar Did you forget to share were “here” is?#2018-12-2117:22bozhidarOh, certainly.#2018-12-2118:30bozhidarHere is https://github.com/nrepl/nrepl/pull/87 🙂#2018-12-2119:44bozhidar> What are the connection means in use today? TCP socket, stdin/stdout and drawbridge?#2018-12-2119:45bozhidarThere’s also fastlane - json/messagepack using transit.#2018-12-2119:45bozhidarAnd the WIP regarding EDN.#2018-12-2119:46bozhidarToday almost everyone is using bencode, and a few people are using drawbridge, but I guess things happened in this manner simply because there were no alternatives until quite recently.#2018-12-2119:46bozhidarI think the new transports would certainly be more convenient for certain clients.#2018-12-2909:53vxeare there any especially difficult obstacles for implementing an nrepl middleware for clojure-clr, perhaps providing something like what piggieback provides for clojurescript?#2018-12-2910:59bozhidar@vxe It’s mostly lack of interest and time. It’s doable, but given the fact that few people use CLR it’s not something high up on our to-do list. It also can’t be done the same way as it’s done for Piggieback, as you can’t drive the evaluation from a JVM, the same way you can do it for ClojureScript.#2018-12-2911:00bozhidarIt would be most feasible to have a separate nREPL implementation for CLR or to use reader conditionals in the current implementation to support CLR.#2018-12-2911:00bozhidarHowever, this would add some complexity for a marginal gain. According to the State of Clojure survey almost no one uses ClojureCLR…#2018-12-2911:11vxenoted, thx#2019-01-0618:47aria42little rusty on things here, but for reasons out of my control, my project has both a org.clojure/tools.nrepl and newer nrepldependency, but lein repl seems to always be picking up the older package name and starting with nREPL 0.2.12. Is this due to lein's dependency on that? I believe I should be overriding, but because the package is different, not sure if I'm actually overriding.#2019-01-0707:08bozhidar@aria42 You need Lein 2.8.3 or newer to use the modern nREPL.#2019-01-0707:08bozhidarOlder versions have tools.nrepl as a hardcoded and non-overridable dep.#2019-01-0707:08bozhidar> Is this due to lein’s dependency on that? In this situation I’ve decided to remove completely support for tools.nrepl in the projects I maintain and just encourage people to upgrade their boot/lein.#2019-01-1417:03eraserhd@bozhidar thanks for adding rep to the clients page!#2019-01-1417:19bozhidarYou’re welcome!#2019-01-1810:29mseddoncomplete and resources-list take a :context parameter, which has the rather cryptic docstring "Completion context for compliment.", what exactly is a 'completion context' and how is it used?#2019-01-1920:43cichli@mseddon see: https://github.com/alexander-yakushev/compliment/wiki/Context#2019-01-1920:45mseddon@cichli Perfect, thanks!#2019-01-1920:48mseddonI had no idea how smart compliment is. Does anyone knows if there's a way for me to transform a string map return from eval to an actual map? But the current pprint default is cider.fipp because that's fine: it would only be interpreted of cider was loaded.#2019-02-1721:35dominicmI suppose fireplace will have to default to clojure.pprint, which is unfortunately slow and prone to StackOverflows#2019-02-1722:30cichliIt’s also a shame how clojure.pprint rebinds *out*, but on the other hand it pretty prints some things that fipp does not (e.g. Datomic entities; see https://github.com/clojure-emacs/cider/issues/1505)#2019-02-1722:37dominicmThat's a benefit of the native integration.#2019-02-1722:38dominicmI wonder if fipp could use pprint instead of prn when unsure. It would hurt performance though.#2019-02-1811:41cichliIt actually just falls back to a tagged representation using str [1][2] and avoids using any of the pr machinery – but I’d say that’s a virtue, since it means fipp can guarantee anything it prints is valid EDN (ignoring the print-length and print-level settings). pr only promises that anything it prints can be read by the Clojure (JVM) reader [1]: https://github.com/brandonbloom/fipp/blob/master/src/fipp/ednize.clj#L38-L42 [2]: https://github.com/brandonbloom/fipp/blob/master/src/fipp/edn.cljc#L68-L73#2019-02-1811:42dominicmpuget seems to do something a bit special here too, going to investigate that a little, but for another project really.#2019-02-1814:37eraserhdI have a bit of polish before first real announce, but select-nrepl is now quite usable. This leverages rewrite-clj and provides ops for finding and selecting the current element, form, or toplevel in some code. https://github.com/eraserhd/select-nrepl#2019-02-1814:39eraserhdIt's smart about what to do if some object is already selected - e.g. repeatedly selecting an element will iterate through elements left-to-right, regardless of nesting. repeatedly selecting forms will find the next-larger form. toplevels will move to the next toplevel.#2019-02-1814:41eraserhd(Also, selecting objects also takes surrounding metadata and other reader embellishments)#2019-02-1814:55dominicmthat's awesome#2019-02-2209:26dominicm@cichli I've had a bug report come my way which appears to be a bug in nrepl 0.6.0's printing stack. https://github.com/rgm/reframe-template/issues/1 I can't see how the replying-PrintWriter function is ever being called, because vim will never send stream? true. Somehow it looks related to the piggieback stack? But I'm not sure of that much either. I was hoping something might stand out to you as why that would be called with that particular stack?#2019-02-2209:48dominicmhttps://github.com/nrepl/nrepl/blob/7721f2f8910faa00a278b52d608a1a6781c2fe0e/src/clojure/nrepl/middleware/interruptible_eval.clj#L76 looks like interruptible eval uses this directly.#2019-02-2209:52cichliIt might be a piggieback issue, it does some manual bookkeeping to make sure *out* and *err* are bound correctly. But I’m not sure why transport would be nil#2019-02-2209:54cichliWhat exactly does :Piggieback eval to start the cljs repl?#2019-02-2210:10dominicm

Oh, fwiw, this is the trace of creating the printwriter#2019-02-2210:11dominicmPiggieback does https://github.com/tpope/vim-fireplace/blob/1ef0f0726cadd96547a5f79103b66339f170da02/plugin/fireplace.vim#L323-L325 So (cider.piggieback/cljs-repl (whatever-you-give-it))#2019-02-2210:12dominicm^ some of the numbers in the stack may be out a little, I've been sprinkling println debugging in#2019-02-2210:14dominicmhttps://github.com/nrepl/nrepl/blob/7721f2f8910faa00a278b52d608a1a6781c2fe0e/src/clojure/nrepl/middleware/session.clj#L140 this looks like it could be the issue? Transport isn't being conveyed here#2019-02-2210:15dominicmAdding :transport there fixes the bug for me#2019-02-2210:20cichliJust realised the same thing 😄#2019-02-2210:20cichliAs a workaround: just make sure you eval something in the session before calling piggieback#2019-02-2210:22cichliI think we don’t want to pass transport there – otherwise initialising the bindings would cause responses to be sent on the transport#2019-02-2210:23cichliBut piggieback should definitely be creating new PrintWriters for each eval message, same as nrepl does. Capturing them from @session is relying on nrepl implementation details#2019-02-2210:30dominicmThat workaround may not work. I think fireplace creates a new session for cljs, which is only available there.#2019-02-2218:47cichliJust looking at the fireplace code, it looks like it does clone up a new session (see line 308). Does adding connection.eval("nil") on the line before the piggieback eval workaround the problem?#2019-02-2218:52dominicm@rgm you'll be at a keyboard sooner than me ^^ :)#2019-02-2219:56cichliIt shouldn’t be needed with the new piggieback though#2019-02-2305:39rgmVictory! OK … so I needed to do a couple things:#2019-02-2305:44rgm1. bump to 0.4.1-SNAPSHOT, 2. Patch fireplace.vim, 3. Make sure a cljs-repl was started in the terminal REPL, before trying to run :Piggieback#2019-02-2305:46rgmso it’s finally working (piggieback + vim/fireplace + figwheel + deps.edn) and I made some notes here: https://github.com/rgm/reframe-template/issues/1#issuecomment-466619263#2019-02-2314:53dominicm@cichli that's working perfectly for me, thanks!#2019-02-2210:31dominicmYou might be able to poke at fireplace to figure it out, but it's not an easy workaround 🙂#2019-02-2210:34cichliYou’re right, it doesn’t use persistent sessions at all IIRC#2019-02-2210:35cichliI have to go catch a train in a few minutes but I’ll get a fix into piggieback this afternoon#2019-02-2210:37dominicm@cichli that's awesome, thank you! ❤️ This was an interesting one to poke at, reminded me that I need to spend some more time working on nrepl 🙂#2019-02-2215:52cichli@rgm @dominicm any chance you could retest with [cider/piggieback "0.4.1-SNAPSHOT"]?#2019-02-2217:14rgmJust tried it and with 0.5.3 and 0.6.0/pback 0.4.1-snapshot I get the same ... progress (?) from this comment: https://github.com/rgm/reframe-template/issues/1#issuecomment-466411581#2019-02-2217:14rgmRunning into a morning of meetings but (again) thanks so much for looking into this.#2019-02-2217:16rgm(This has that feeling like there’s a stack of errors of use, my own misconceptions and new-to-discover minor bugs that I’ll just have to pop one by one, so I really appreciate the help).#2019-02-2219:56cichliIf I connect to a regular Clojure REPL and start a CLJS REPL manually with: (cider.piggieback/cljs-repl (figwheel.main.api/repl-env "config/dev")) then I don’t get the nil IReplEnvOption error, but the first evaluation does raise that same Error: Cannot find module '@cljs-oss/module-deps'#2019-02-2219:57cichliPossibly related? ssh -vNL 40000:localhost:65432 my-remote-host
i verify there's a connection (at least i think this means it worked) 
nc -vv localhost 40000
found 0 associations
found 1 connections:
     1: flags=82<CONNECTED,PREFERRED>
        outif lo0
        src ::1 port 65316
        dst ::1 port 40000
        rank info not available
        TCP aux info available

Connection to localhost port 40000 [tcp/safetynetp] succeeded!
then try to connect a repl client: 
lein repl :connect localhost:40000

Please declare all middleware in :middleware as implicit loading is deprecated.

#2019-02-2316:51devthverified i can: 1. ssh to host 2. docker exec into container 3. run lein connect and get a repl#2019-02-2303:39hiredmanthe jvm might be prefering the ipv6 address for localhost#2019-02-2405:27craftybonesAnybody here?#2019-02-2407:03dominicmYes#2019-02-2422:34cflemingI’m chatting over in #rebl with people trying to get https://github.com/RickMoynihan/nrebl.middleware to work.#2019-02-2422:35cflemingMy understanding is that in nrepl responses, the :value should always be a string, since it’s the pr-stred evaluation result.#2019-02-2422:36cflemingThe doc backs that up: https://nrepl.org/nrepl/0.6.0/design/overview.html#_responses > value The result of printing a result of evaluating a form in the code sent in the corresponding request.#2019-02-2422:36cflemingI’m still on the old nrepl, and that has always been true there.#2019-02-2422:37cfleming@maxt has been doing some experimentation, and is sometimes seeing nil values in responses.#2019-02-2422:51maxtnrebl.middleware implements Transport send, which gets the same request twice, but with different keys in the response map. First time it includes :value, the second time it gets :status #{:done} without value.#2019-02-2422:54cfleming@maxt That is expected - not all messages include a :value#2019-02-2422:55cflemingDoes that mean that when you’re getting nil from :value, that it’s just because there’s no :value entry at all?#2019-02-2422:55maxtYes, I just read up on that.#2019-02-2422:57maxt@cfleming most likley. I'll test to wrap it in a check for the existence of the :value key.#2019-02-2422:57maxtCould :value ever be nil?#2019-02-2422:58maxtSimply wrapping it in (when value ,,,) works great from what I can see.#2019-02-2422:58cflemingOver in #rebl, @lilactown has reported that he does indeed see the values correctly in REBL, using CIDER and nREPL 0.5.x. Could it be that the CIDER middleware is causing the :value to be an actual value, i.e. a non-`pr-str`ed string?#2019-02-2422:59cfleming@maxt In my experience (all with old nREPL), if that :value is present it is never nil.#2019-02-2422:59cflemingBut (when value ...) seems like a fine check to me.#2019-02-2423:00cflemingActually, looking at the Cursive code I do (when-let [val (:value item)] so I’d never know if there were nil values, but they seem safe to ignore if there ever are any.#2019-02-2423:49maxt@cfleming This patch seems to work well for me in Cursive. https://github.com/RickMoynihan/nrebl.middleware/pull/16 I can also successfully combine it with https://github.com/RickMoynihan/nrebl.middleware/pull/11 to get a nrepl REBL working as a clojure.main rebel. I have not, however, tested it with any other editor.#2019-02-2423:51dpsuttonI think @cichli has been doing a lot of work on nrepl recently and might have some thoughts#2019-02-2500:03maxt@cfleming Still one issue with together with Cursive. When I send forms from the editor, they get wrapped in a long expression. Sending from the repl-window doesn't have this problem.#2019-02-2500:17maxt@cfleming I see now that's already reported https://github.com/cursive-ide/cursive/issues/2113#2019-02-2500:32cfleming@maxt Yes, I’m planning to fix #2113 in the next build.#2019-02-2500:33maxtGreat!#2019-02-2502:15cflemingI found another incompatibility that isn’t documented at https://nrepl.org/nrepl/0.6.0/installation.html#upgrading - on the nrepl.server.Server record, the ss field has changed to server-socket. Probably a good change, but one that clients might be using.#2019-02-2502:15cflemingI use that for printing out the port that the REPL server started on.#2019-03-0313:33Jon
