Exception in thread "main" java.lang.RuntimeException: No such var: nrepl.transport/uri-scheme, compiling:(/private/var/folders/fw/gd1yg_sd5sx_dvqv5pnk6f3m0000gn/T/form-init4758704793550975827.clj:1:3327)
    at clojure.lang.Compiler.analyze(Compiler.java:6792)
    at clojure.lang.Compiler.analyze(Compiler.java:6729)
#2019-03-2620:54cflemingCursive doesn’t use that var at all, and I’m awaiting details on what his stack looks like. But does that look familiar to anyone?#2019-03-2620:55cflemingI assume it’s a conflict between the new nREPL and piggieback or something similar.#2019-03-2620:56cflemingThe var that’s required but missing is in the new nREPL namespace though, strangely.#2019-03-2623:16cflemingActually, I suspect that this might be a lein version incompatibility, and the nREPL upgrade is a red herring. I’m waiting for feedback to confirm that.#2019-03-2706:16bozhidar@cfleming That’s the first time I see such an error. That new var is simply a way for tools like Lein to print properly the nREPL url now that it has more transports (before all tools had hardcoded nrepl://). The var was actually added in nREPL 0.5.#2019-03-2706:18bozhidarhttps://github.com/nrepl/nrepl/blob/master/src/clojure/nrepl/transport.clj#L220#2019-03-2706:19bozhidarWhat’s his piggieback version? Your user should be on 0.4 for things to work properly.#2019-03-2709:09cfleming@bozhidar Actually, it’s not the first time you’ve seen it :-): https://github.com/eraserhd/rep/issues/1#2019-03-2709:10cflemingI’m waiting for some details on his setup, such as piggieback version.#2019-03-2709:19cflemingI’ll let him know that 0.4 is what he should be using.#2019-03-2709:20bozhidar> https://github.com/eraserhd/rep/issues/1 It’s different here - he injected an older version of nREPL when Lein expected a newer one. I think you mentioned your user was on 0.6, that’s why I can imagine how this can be missing.#2019-03-2709:25cflemingYeah, I don’t know much about his setup - he just said it’s a CLJS project and he gets the error at startup. But I think the fact that Cursive has upgraded the nREPL it uses is misleading, since if he’s using lein that version won’t be used anyway, it’ll be whatever lein is using.#2019-03-2709:27cflemingI suspect that upgrading Cursive will have caused him to use a later leiningen, which is incompatible with whatever piggieback he’s using, but I’m not sure yet.#2019-03-2709:40cflemingAwesome, problem was fixed by upgrading nREPL and Piggieback.#2019-03-2710:21bozhidarGreat!#2019-03-2710:22bozhidarHow does Cursive start nREPL itself, btw? It doesn’t use any build tool and sorts out the projects deps itself?#2019-03-2710:24cflemingThat’s used when someone wants a REPL in a project that’s not managed by something like lein that will start a REPL for you. So things like Gradle or Maven, or a manually configured project. Then, right, Cursive will use the IntelliJ classpath and just add nREPL to it, and then inject an init script which starts the server.#2019-03-2710:33bozhidarUnderstood. That sounds neat!#2019-03-2710:34cflemingYeah, I use it a lot since I use Gradle a fair bit for mixed Clojure/Kotlin projects (Cursive itself, in particular).#2019-03-2711:47bozhidarI haven’t used Gradle since my days as a Java programmer. 🙂#2019-03-2916:46bozhidarA long overdue article https://metaredux.com/posts/2019/03/29/nrepl-0-6.html#2019-03-2916:49dpsutton#announcements ?#2019-03-2917:20bozhidarIt was released 2 months ago. 🙂#2019-03-2917:25dpsuttonannounce the informative post 🙂#2019-03-2918:48bozhidarDone!#2019-03-2921:03cflemingDoes the new nREPL actually require Java 8 for anything? I didn’t realise it had that dependency, and have started receiving issues from users who are using JDK7.#2019-03-2921:31dpsuttonthe change points here: https://github.com/nrepl/nREPL/issues/26#2019-03-2921:41dpsuttonall tests pass with :javac-options ["-target" "6" "-source" "6"]#2019-03-2921:41dpsuttonnot sure if that's dispositive or not#2019-03-2921:45cfleming@dpsutton Thanks! Since the version in Cursive is only used when Cursive starts its own REPL, perhaps I’ll fork a version compiled against Java 6. But in general, it seems like it would be good to support older versions if newer ones are not required for anything.#2019-03-2921:46dpsuttonfrom the ticket it doesn't look like raising the bar was ~intended~ unintended. I guess @bozhidar took 8 to be the current java version rather than the current bytecode version?#2019-03-2921:46dpsuttonit was usually 6 for clojure until 1.10 right?#2019-03-2921:46dpsutton(unless i'm conflating issues)#2019-03-2921:47cflemingYes, that’s right.#2019-03-2921:47cflemingBut Cursive is used a lot in enterprise environments, where upgrading is often not a choice.#2019-03-2921:47dpsuttonfor sure#2019-03-2921:47dpsuttonis this just in an EAP?#2019-03-2921:48dpsuttonor have you gone full nrepl 6 in the main version?#2019-03-2921:48cflemingNo, I released it in the latest stable release, I hadn’t realised that it had a Java 8 dep.#2019-03-2921:48dpsuttonah. shucks#2019-03-2921:49cflemingWell, when users start a REPL via lein or deps, you get whatever they use, which is probably 90% of the REPL use. But some users start a REPL in a project not managed by one of those two (e.g. Maven, Gradle, manual project setup or some other means), and then Cursive injects nREPL to start the server.#2019-03-2921:50cflemingIn that case, it uses the version bundled with Cursive, which is now 0.6#2019-03-3009:54bozhidar@cfleming It probably works on Java 6, but I have no idea. It became hard to test against 6 at some point and I decided it wasn’t worth it. I’m reasonably certain it should work well with 7.#2019-03-3009:55cfleming@bozhidar Ok, I’ll probably fork and create a Java 6 version to bundle with Cursive then.#2019-03-3009:55bozhidarIt certainly doesn’t using anything special introduced in Java 8. I just removed 6 and 7 from the build matrix and changed the compiler flag.#2019-03-3009:58bozhidarIt’s interesting that no one had asked about Java 6 and 7 so far. I just assumed even enterprises had updated by now. 🙂 I do assume we’d be stuck on Java 8 forever, though.#2019-03-3011:39shenWhat would be involved in supporting java 6 and 7?#2019-03-3011:39shenthe javac flag? or do we need a way to test?#2019-03-3013:09bozhidarIt’s just a matter of tweaking :javac-options ["-target" "8" "-source" "8"] in project.clj.#2019-03-3013:10bozhidarI think it has been set to Java 8 for quite a while now, but I don’t remember how long exactly.#2019-03-3013:13bozhidarSomeone has to test this to make sure it actually works, I removed those JDKs from the CI when they were removed by Travis. Plus the build matrix had become huge (and the tests on Travis were super slow) and it seemed pointless to test platforms which weren’t used much, anyways.#2019-03-3014:35bozhidarJust confirmed - Java 8 has been the compilation target pretty much since the beginning of the new nREPL. See https://github.com/nrepl/nrepl/commit/90db7f9b36a35fa9fff8691a1e121e284ab5fdf4#2019-03-3014:36bozhidar@cfleming What was the version of nREPL Cursive bundled before? I was under the impression you had switched to nrepl/nrepl a while ago.#2019-03-3015:49shenI've been looking at testing with Java 1.6 and 1.7 on CircleCI#2019-03-3015:51shenthe tricky part is finding a suitable Docker image. CircleCi's ones are based on the official Clojure images, which are, in turn, based on the Docker official OpenJDK ones#2019-03-3015:52shenThere are OpenJDK java 7 (and of interest, 12 and 13-ea) images, but the Clojure, and thus CircleCI ones, don't follow#2019-03-3021:35cfleming@bozhidar No, my switch was very recent. I’ve been talking about doing it for a while 🙂#2019-03-3021:47bozhidarGot it.#2019-03-3021:47bozhidar> There are OpenJDK java 7 (and of interest, 12 and 13-ea) images, but the Clojure, and thus CircleCI ones, don’t follow#2019-03-3021:48bozhidarI imagined as much. TravisCI removed JDK 6 and 7 a while ago. Seems most people have written them off at this point.#2019-03-3021:53bozhidarI’d be fine with updating the build target upstream as well. I went over the code and I don’t see anything requiring JDK > 6. It’d be nice if we managed to run the tests somehow to be on the safe side, though. 😄#2019-04-0814:36lilactownI’m considering trying to connect to nREPL from a web app / chrome extension for a project. is there any prior art for something like this?#2019-04-0814:36dominicmDrawbridge I think#2019-04-0814:36lilactownI’m looking at drawbridge, which seems like it might be the way to go.#2019-04-0814:36lilactownyeah#2019-04-0814:37lilactownI’m a bit bummed that it requires a separate dep. the dream would be that I could just connect to any old nREPL server#2019-04-0814:41shenThink the fundamental limit is that a web app will need to speak http or ws#2019-04-0814:51shenand I don't think Java standard libraries provide either of those.#2019-04-0814:52lilactownyeah. I wish there was some way for Chrome to connect to a regular ol’ socket 😭 pulling in an HTTP server for every project using nREPL seems potentially problematic#2019-04-0814:56bozhidar> I’m a bit bummed that it requires a separate dep. the dream would be that I could just connect to any old nREPL server (edited)#2019-04-0814:57bozhidarThat’s hard to do as you need to bundle somehow an HTTP server with the REPL. Leiningen used to ship Drawbridge at some point, but I’m not sure if that’s still the case.#2019-04-0814:58bozhidarIn theory we could have a trivial self-contained http implementation bundled with nREPL, but there never was a lot of demand for this.#2019-04-0815:00lilactownmakes sense.#2019-04-0815:03lilactownwould you take a PR with something like that? I might be able to put something together, but I also understand if it’s just increasing surface area to support for something not many other people need#2019-04-0815:04shenwhat's the usecase here, @lilactown?#2019-04-0815:05lilactownI’m working on some devtooling a la REBL for the browser#2019-04-0815:07lilactownI previously implemented my own shoddy protocol on top of websockets for Node.js / JVM, but I was thinking i might be able to simplify my life by just connecting directly to a REPL#2019-04-0815:10dominicmI think the side loading work might be useful here?#2019-04-0815:10dominicmI guess not actually, as you can't sideload a transport#2019-04-0815:11lilactownspecifically I’m now pivoting to a chrome extension that would connect to a remote session: CLJS in an inspected page, Node.js, and JVM. I previously implemented different “adapters” for each platform, but I know that most projects already have nREPL which would reduce dependencies users would have to install and potentially reduce the differences in implementation#2019-04-0815:11shenthis might be useful?#2019-04-0815:11shenhttps://github.com/tomjakubowski/weasel#2019-04-0815:13lilactownI looked at that as well. it’s still another transport, right? and it didn’t look like it had been updated in awhile, so I wasn’t sure if it supported the latest nREPL#2019-04-0815:13shenI imagine step one is getting this all to work with drawbridge/your own http transport#2019-04-0815:14shenand then check if it's worth trying to merge the functionality into nREPL#2019-04-0815:15shenI've seen some roll-your-own HTTP implementations, and if you are super narrow about the usecase, it can be manageable. But all depends on what it looks like#2019-04-0815:15lilactownyeah. I’m afraid that it will bloom into “now nREPL has a fully-fledged HTTP server impl” lol#2019-04-0815:36bozhidar> I looked at that as well. it’s still another transport, right? and it didn’t look like it had been updated in awhile, so I wasn’t sure if it supported the latest nREPL#2019-04-0815:37bozhidarNot really. It’s just a ClojureScript REPL based on piggieback.#2019-04-0815:52shenisn't it a way to speak to piggieback via a websocket?#2019-04-0815:52shenthink it's part of boot's counterpart to lein-figwheel#2019-04-0815:38bozhidar> yeah. I’m afraid that it will bloom into “now nREPL has a fully-fledged HTTP server impl” lol#2019-04-0815:38bozhidarThat’s always a possible outcome. 😄#2019-04-0815:39bozhidar> I guess not actually, as you can’t sideload a transport#2019-04-0815:40bozhidar@dominicm You won’t need to sideload it, thouhg. You could inject it in the initial payload you’d use to convert a socket repl to nREPL. Once we get there that is. @cgrand already has some branch where the injection works, so I guess that’d be just an extension of this idea.#2019-04-0816:03cgrandhmm no the injection is not done yet (been busy)#2019-04-0816:09bozhidaryeah, I know. Just remember that demo you showed me way back in December and that we spoke that the injection could be a good way to provide custom transports seamlessly.#2019-04-0816:13dominicm@bozhidar I don't think that browsers let you make arbitrary socket calls.#2019-04-0816:16bozhidarGood point. That approach would work for conventional clients, but not for @lilactown’s use case.#2019-04-0816:18lilactownI kind of want just a dumb endpoint that I could dump some code into to “inject” stuff, like a heavier HTTP transport if needed#2019-04-0817:35dominicmAn interesting idea would be to have the default transport allow sideloading via a very dumb detection of http request#2019-04-0817:36dominicmNot sure how much parsing would be needed for the cases we want to support.#2019-04-1209:58roklenarcicIn https://github.com/nrepl/piggieback readme there's this instruction.

I think I should be able to keep my repl client standing, and if so it is not a stopper.#2019-04-2415:03pezBut I haven't really tried fixing it on my end yet, Just very rececently realized the problem was there.#2019-04-2415:08pezI have a pretty reproducable problem with those version combos I mentioned above. With the older set of versions, out and err messages arrive as I expect them to, but with the newer set, those messages are gone. What is pr_values, btw?#2019-04-2415:10bozhidarIt used to be the middleware that converted EDN values into strings that can go in the :value slot.#2019-04-2415:11bozhidarIt was replaced by a similar, but more flexible print middleware.#2019-04-2415:13bozhidar> With the older set of versions, out and err messages arrive as I expect them to, but with the newer set, those messages are gone#2019-04-2415:13bozhidarThey behave now the same way they always did.#2019-04-2415:14bozhidarThat’s what happened to pr_values - https://nrepl.org/nrepl/0.6.0/design/middleware.html#_pretty_printing#2019-04-2415:14bozhidarI think you’ll find it very useful.#2019-04-2415:15bozhidarYour error indicates that somehow the print transport is nil for you, but I can’t imagine how this can happen. Maybe you’re passing some weird params in the eval request?#2019-04-2415:28pezMaybe I am. Will investigate deeper tonight, and let you know if I still think the problem is with the new versions. But thing is that even with the new versions the clj repl behaves as I expect, it is only the cljs repl that gives me grief.#2019-04-2415:37bozhidarThat’s pretty weird. This has been out for 3 months now and no one has reported similar issues.#2019-04-2415:42pezI'll try to produce a repro. What will probably happen is that I find out what i am doing wrong. #2019-04-2415:43bozhidar:thumbsup:#2019-04-2511:37pezStatus report, @bozhidar: In trying to isolate a repro I have found that my nrepl client was sometimes relying on a specific order of messages returned for a request. (Or, not really order, but I was resolving my promises too early). I am pretty sure this is the problem, but I will dig a bit further before I am ready to conclude so. It would at least explain why something might have changed w/o anyone complaining, but me. 😃#2019-04-2511:58bozhidarRoger that! Looking forward to seeing the conclusion of your investigation.#2019-04-2520:51pezOK, so that was a good exercise for me. The hard Leiningen dep on 0.6.0 meant I had to use other tools and it was about time I checked out clj/deps and Figwheel main, anyway. It was like I had already sort of found out. When there’s an error in an evaluation the ex and err messages come in different order and I had a check for eval-error that terminated my waiting for done and caused a disturbance in the force. But the real havoc was caused by me not realizing that Leiningen did not care about me injecting some other nrepl version, so your guess about a version mismatch was on target, @bozhidar. Now there’s hope for Calva Jack-in again.#2019-04-2521:02pezI made a little script that runs a sequence of nrepl evals, first on the CLJ repl, then with the CLJS one. Here are the results from running the script on the two sets of nrepl dependencies that I have been trying to use lately.#2019-04-2611:20flowthingI'd like to do the equivalent of lein repl :connect with clj. That is, something along the lines of clj -Sdeps '{:deps {nrepl {:mvn/version "0.6.0"} nrepl/drawbridge {:mvn/version "0.2.0"}}}' -m nrepl.cmdline --interactive --connect --url . I think that's currently not possible, since the --url flag doesn't exist. Would it make sense to add something like that?#2019-04-2612:36flowthing...although it's pretty easy to just do something like that yourself. I pieced together a small app that connects to a Drawbridge nREPL endpoint and uses rebel-readline for the REPL stuff.#2019-04-2613:07pezTried --host and --port?#2019-04-2706:27flowthingYes, but if the Drawbridge endpoint is e.g. at http://localhost:3001/repl, host and port isn't enough, need to pass the /repl bit as well. And anyway, connecting to a Drawbridge endpoint is done via nrepl/url-connect, whereas nrepl.cmdline currently uses nrepl/connect.#2019-04-2707:02pezGotcha. Completly missed the /repl part.#2019-04-2614:48bozhidarThe problem is that for connect to know how to handle http, drawbridge has to have been required already. There’s no real need for a separate param. We just need to add some check in the cmd client to require the drawbridge client ns (if present).#2019-04-2614:49bozhidarThat’s a common problem for all third-party transports url-connect should be made aware of them somehow, so it’d work with them.#2019-04-2712:14pezOK. clojure -Sdeps "{:deps {nrepl {:mvn/version \"0.6.0\"} cider/cider-nrepl {:mvn/version \"0.21.1\"} cider/piggieback {:mvn/version \"0.4.0\"} figwheel-sidecar {:mvn/version \"0.5.18\"}}}" -m nrepl.cmdline --middleware "[cider.nrepl/cider-middleware cider.piggieback/wrap-cljs-repl]"
#2019-04-2714:56pezThen it depends on project type for the cljs repl, but for figwheel: 
(do (require 'figwheel-sidecar.repl-api) (if (not (figwheel-sidecar.repl-api/figwheel-running?)) (figwheel-sidecar.repl-api/start-figwheel!)) (figwheel-sidecar.repl-api/cljs-repl))

For those cases you need to start a new server from the updated code.#2019-05-0113:54bozhidarI know what you mean. The state message, coming after done.#2019-05-0208:39pezYes, only for ClojureScript.#2019-05-0208:41pez(The reason my client doesn't log the state there is that I stop listening once I have gotten the done.)#2019-05-0208:43pezBut maybe I should be alert on : changed-namespaces... I notice that my repl prompt is sometimes lying...#2019-05-0208:44pezWith these tests, I get the same behaviour in 0.6.0 as in master, just as you expected, btw.#2019-05-0208:49bozhidar> But maybe I should be alert on : changed-namespaces... I notice that my repl prompt is sometimes lying...#2019-05-0208:49bozhidarYou can safely ignore this. This middleware is in cider-nrepl and it tracks updates to namespaces, so the client to can act efficiently on them.#2019-05-0208:50bozhidarMost notably it provides you an up-to-date list of vars in the namespace so you can syntax highlight them accordingly.#2019-05-0208:51bozhidarWe also use this in CIDER to show notifications that that source code and the REPL are in sync (meaning everything has been evaluated).#2019-05-0208:52pezI'll implement that stuff once I've gotten this crazy println thing under control. 😃#2019-05-0208:52bozhidarProbably we should add some way for the middleware to be disabled without having to be removed from the middleware graph, for clients that don’t need it.#2019-05-0208:52bozhidarIn generates a lot of messages which are confusing if someone doesn’t need it.#2019-05-0208:53pezHuge messages, even. 😃#2019-05-0208:54pezWhen I evaluate in a project that uses Figwheel Main and using the clojars 0.6.0, I get this when evaluating a printn:

nrc receiving: {"ex":"class java.lang.IllegalArgumentException","id":"16","root-ex":"class java.lang.IllegalArgumentException","session":"b282a095-a368-4ffd-9fc3-dec8549cbc2d","status":["eval-error"]}

printing-transport: {:id "74", :session "41106734-a7e2-4b75-8509-d4a44f545601", "file" nil, "line" 1, "ns" "clojure.live-cljs-hacking", "doc" nil, "name" "clojure.live-cljs-hacking", :status #{:done}}

#2019-05-1412:25bozhidarI think @pez mentioned a similar problem (take a look at this history).#2019-05-1412:25pezYes, I've seen it often with the dev build of Calva, which seems to provoke this thing often. I have failed to trace it down, though.#2019-05-1412:25bozhidarI haven’t been able to reproduce it, though.#2019-05-1412:25pezThe history is eaten by the 10K monster.#2019-05-1412:27bozhidarAh, damn it. My best guess is that the problem happens only with a certain format of the evaluation requests, as no CIDER users have ever reported this.#2019-05-1412:27dominicm@cichli helped me with this before#2019-05-1412:27dominicmIt might be fixed in snapshot piggieback?#2019-05-1412:27bozhidarHe hasn’t been around much lately, but he’s definitely the expert on this part of the code.#2019-05-1412:28pezMy theory has been that it is provoked by something that happens before the evaluation request.#2019-05-1412:29bozhidarOne thing that comes to mind is that CIDER uses streamed values by default. I wonder if the problem happens only without them.#2019-05-1412:29bozhidar> It might be fixed in snapshot piggieback?#2019-05-1412:29bozhidarGood idea. @cichli did some refactorings there, although I don’t think anything related to bug reports.#2019-05-1412:30pezI shall see if it is still easy to get this with Calva, if so I can also check wether snapshot fixes it.#2019-05-1412:36markwoodhallI am hitting the problem consistently, I have just tried with piggieback 0.4.1-SNAPSHOT and the issue went away. Will keep trying and see how I get on.#2019-05-1412:46markwoodhallI did look at the diff between 0.4.0 and 0.4.1-SNAPSHOT and it looked like nothing there could resolve it, it looks like it has though.#2019-05-1412:53bozhidar@markwoodhall That’s an unexpected, but welcome development. I can cut a release for 0.4.1 is a day or two. Let’s just make sure that the problem goes away for good.#2019-05-1412:54bozhidarAh, I’m pretty sure that’s the bug fix https://github.com/nrepl/piggieback/commit/f43e12c13725e2bd31b944d39a55b38dd6b5587c#2019-05-1413:00bozhidarIn light of this revelation I’ve just released 0.4.1 right away. I’m just sorry poor @pez wasted a ton of time debugging this, before @dominicm saved us.#2019-05-1413:03pezHaha, I learnt a lot in the process, shed no tears my way. ❤️#2019-05-1607:29bozhidarAfter several quiet months I’ve created a bunch of nREPL tickets with a few ideas I have for the future. They are mostly about promoting some things we’ve developed for cider-nrepl upstream.#2019-05-1607:30bozhidarOn a related note - I might cut 0.7 soon only with @shen’s work on the EDN transport, as there has been no traction on the other fronts unfortunately.#2019-05-1717:54urzdsHi!#2019-05-1717:55urzdsIs there an nREPL multiplexer? Something like tmux or screen, but for nREPL? Something that allows multiple nREPL clients to connect to the same process and see the same output and receive the same results from functions and catch the same exceptions?#2019-05-1720:03dominicmThere is cider-spy in this space#2019-05-1802:31bozhidarThere was also https://github.com/jamii/concerto/ at some point.#2019-05-1802:32bozhidarGenerally creating a multiplexer shouldn’t be particularly hard.#2019-05-1806:47dominicmI suspect that client support is the hard part#2019-05-1906:44bozhidarYeah, although it shouldn’t be particularly hard.#2019-05-2009:43urzdsThanks!#2019-06-0110:40pezI have a strange situation with my work project (Leiningen + lein-figwheel), with four different behaviours on four different machines. Starting it headless I can’t start figwheel. I get Execution error (IllegalArgumentException) at figwheel-sidecar.utils/illegal-argument (utils.clj:53) when it tries to require the namespace with my figwheel :ring-handler. B. I can start the project with an interactive repl. And then also start fighweel from that repl. However if I start the repl :headless I get the same error as with A when trying to start figwheel. C. I can start the repl interactive or headless and also start fighweel regardless. It is all Macs with latest macos and all are using Java 8 (because reasons). Not sure where to post this, but figured that in this channel there is the knowledge that might help me pinpoint where the problem stems from.#2019-06-0317:32pezHello, I am going to appear on a Clojure podcast soon, to talk about Calva. In pondering what the heck to say, I started to think about how nice it would be to be able to use Calva together with Lumo. From what I understand, a big hurdle there is the lack of an nrepl server. But I have also heard rumours about an nrepl server being possible on top of the socket server. Is that so? What can you share about the prospects of using an nrepl client with self hosted ClojureScript?#2019-06-0317:38dominicm@pez I think that the trick doesn't work in clojurescript because the repl is a little special. It might be workable for lumo, I can't remember if the changes were made to it's repl function. Nrepl is still mostly written with jvm in mind though, so I imagine there would need to be a lot of changes.#2019-06-0317:38dominicmThe unrepl wiki has notes on clojurescript#2019-06-0317:39pezThanks! I'll have a look. #2019-06-0318:59pezI didn’t understand much about what was said about cljs on that wiki. But I found an issue that self hosted cljs support is on @cgrand’s wishlist. However, I also do not know what unrepl support for self hosted cljs would mean for Calva. I’ll stay away from discussing it on the podcast, but am of course very curious.#2019-06-0319:21dominicm:) I'd mention it's of interest, but still a research topic#2019-06-0319:25dominicmSomeone could step up and pioneer it, and they'd find support from this channel#2019-06-0407:27bozhidar> I have a strange situation with my work project (Leiningen + lein-figwheel), with four different behaviours on four different machines. Let’s call them A, B, C and D .#2019-06-0407:28bozhidar@pez Did you manage to sort this out? The problems you described didn’t seem nREPL related to me, more like something to do with Lein.#2019-06-0407:28bozhidar> Hello, I am going to appear on a Clojure podcast soon, to talk about Calva. In pondering what the heck to say, I started to think about how nice it would be to be able to use Calva together with Lumo. From what I understand, a big hurdle there is the lack of an nrepl server. But I have also heard rumours about an nrepl server being possible on top of the socket server. Is that so? What can you share about the prospects of using an nrepl client with self hosted ClojureScript?#2019-06-0407:30bozhidarAdding to what was already said here - I think that implementing an nREPL server in ClojureScript won’t be hard, provided someone decides to tackle it. But the real difficulty would be the broader ecosystem of middleware - most of them rely on Java in one way or another and porting a lot of middleware is obviously a lot of work.#2019-06-0407:31bozhidarThat’s why we avoided in general the route of the self-hosted nREPL for ClojureScript and tried to do as much as possible with the boostrapped version - this simplified a lot the work needed to provide “some” ClojureScript support.#2019-06-0407:32bozhidarIn the end of the day it’s always fairly simply to provide some basic eval functionality, but the more complex the features get, the harder it is to avoid using some host features.#2019-06-0407:32bozhidar> However, I also do not know what unrepl support for self hosted cljs would mean for Calva.#2019-06-0407:32pezRe: my timeout problems. I thought it might be nrepl related a while because had different results with some different dependencies injected, but that was a smoke screen it seems. It is probably something to do with some libraries we use. We'll figure it out, hopefully.#2019-06-0407:33bozhidarI assume it would mean nothing, as you’d have to implement a different API if you want to support unrepl/prepl.#2019-06-0407:52dominicmTo clarify my intention here, unrepl's problem with running over a socket repl are the same problems that nrepl will have, same approach.#2019-06-0407:53bozhidarYep, exactly.#2019-06-0407:34bozhidarI spent some time researching the possibility for supporting different REPL providers in CIDER in the past, but in the end it seemed like too much work for very little gain.#2019-06-0407:34pezCalva is pretty bare bones. So probably not a lot of middleware involved.#2019-06-0407:34bozhidarYou basically need to provide an abstraction layer over nrepl/unrepl/prepl and have to reconcile the differences between them in that layer.#2019-06-0407:36bozhidarIf you’re mostly using eval I guess you can get away with an nREPL implementation that simply doesn’t support middleware at all and just provides the ops you need for Calva.#2019-06-0407:36bozhidarI know that’s what Arcadia’s team did to build a working nREPL server for ClojureCLR. Their implementation was something like one file and would be a good starting point for ClojureScript support as well.#2019-06-0407:37pezCool. I'll have a look at that. Arcadia is another environment I'd like Calva to be useful with anyway.#2019-06-0407:39bozhidarFor Arcadia it’s simpler in general - I think the piggieback approach (just provide eval support via middleware) would work for them.#2019-06-0407:39bozhidarHere’s actually an implementation of that https://github.com/spacepluk/arcadia.nrepl/blob/master/src/arcadia/nrepl.clj#2019-06-0407:40bozhidar> This is an nREPL bridge for Arcadia Unity. It spins up a standard nREPL server and it redirects eval operations to the Arcadia UDP REPL. This will allow to use existing tooling and editor integrations without the need to port nREPL and other middlewares/libraries to ClojureCLR.#2019-06-0407:40bozhidarThat’s the beauty of nREPL modular architecture in action. 🙂#2019-06-0407:43pezYou are making me cry here. 😃#2019-06-0407:52dominicmTo clarify my intention here, unrepl's problem with running over a socket repl are the same problems that nrepl will have, same approach.#2019-06-0407:53bozhidar@pez I didn’t want to ruin your day. 😉#2019-06-0407:55pezHaha, I just have a soft spot for beauty.#2019-06-0408:49bozhidar😄 😄 😄#2019-06-2112:38bozhidarFYI - https://metaredux.com/posts/2019/06/21/nrepl-0-7-introducing-a-native-edn-transport.html#2019-06-2113:56stathissiderishello#2019-06-2113:57stathissiderisI tried:

I’m certain this will work.#2019-06-2513:15pezIs that how CIDER does it?#2019-06-2513:15bozhidarCIDER never clones any existing sessions, so I never played much with this.#2019-06-2513:15pezInteresting.#2019-06-2513:16bozhidarI think you should at least open a ticket about this on nREPL (or piggieback’s repo), so we would investigate this further at some point.#2019-06-2513:16pezI'll do that. What session bindings should I inspect?#2019-06-2513:16bozhidarClose is supposed to clone most session bindings, but I don’t remember which one exactly.#2019-06-2513:19pezI'll inspect some bindings and see if I can figure it out. 😃#2019-06-2513:20pezI was certain that starting off with cloning the session you get when you connect was the way you should do it. So how does CIDER do these things?#2019-06-2513:21bozhidar*cljs-repl-env* this one for instance.#2019-06-2513:23bozhidarJust pull those from the session like this https://github.com/clojure-emacs/cider-nrepl/blob/master/src/cider/nrepl/middleware/util/cljs.clj#L53#2019-06-2513:24bozhidar> I was certain that starting off with cloning the session you get when you connect was the way you should do it.#2019-06-2513:25bozhidarCIDER sets up two basic sessions for each logical connection - one for evaluations and one for everything else (aka the tooling session). The second is cloned from the first.#2019-06-2513:26bozhidarThey can be upgraded to ClojureScript later if needed, but we always start off with Clojure sessions.#2019-06-2513:26bozhidarI think that’s most historical. When the project was created ClojureScript simply didn’t exist.#2019-06-2606:10pezI'm not sure how to pull those from the session. I can't evaluate anything in it. Which is very different from if it was just a plain session again. It is instead something in between...#2019-06-2607:19pezI created this issue, @bozhidar: https://github.com/nrepl/piggieback/issues/105#2019-06-2607:19pezPlease let me know if it needs more/different info.#2019-06-2608:29bozhidar@pez Thanks!#2019-06-2608:30bozhidar> Hi all. Im running an embedded nrepl inside a mixed java/clojure project. Is there anyway to expose a user.clj or equivalent for some start/reset/stop functions?#2019-06-2608:30bozhidar@galvs I’m not quite sure what you need to do so a bit more context would be useful.#2019-07-0217:25nwjsmithhttps://clojurians.slack.com/archives/C0617A8PQ/p1562088112489600#2019-07-0820:31mkarpHey everyone! Any ideas how to improve it are appreciated#2019-07-0906:11bozhidarKeep in mind that you can have evaluations without a file anyways - e.g. those coming from a REPL.#2019-07-0912:07mkarp@bozhidar Thank you!                 .invoke(Symbol.intern("nrepl.cmdline"));
#2019-07-1918:02phreedI have also tried this style http://clojure.github.io/clojure/javadoc/clojure/java/api/package-summary.html with similar results. 
final IFn plus = Clojure.var("clojure.core", "+");
#2019-07-1918:15phreedI think I see the problem. https://github.com/clojure/clojure/blob/master/src/jvm/clojure/lang/Compiler.java#L274 The value of some of the system properties is null.#2019-07-1919:01phreedHere is the code that seems to work for me: 
public void init()
    {
        ("init for plugin");
        for (Map.Entry entry : System.getProperties().entrySet())
        {
            String name = (String) entry.getKey();
            try
            {
                String value = (String) entry.getValue();
                ("key: {}, value: {}", name, value);
            } catch (ClassCastException ex) {
                //javax.swing.JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(
                //        null,
                //        entry.getKey().toString() + " : " + entry.getValue().toString());
                entry.setValue("");
                ("key: {}, null value", name);
            }

        }

        // (clojure.core/+ 1 2)
        final IFn plus = Clojure.var("clojure.core", "+");
        final Object object = plus.invoke(1, 2);

        log.debug("plus invoked, result was: {}", object);

        // (clojure.core/require clojure.tools.nrepl.server)
        final IFn require = Clojure.var("clojure.core", "require");
        require.invoke(Clojure.read("nrepl.server"));

        // (clojure.tools.nrepl.server/start-server :port 12000)
        final IFn server = Clojure.var("nrepl.server", "start-server");
        server.invoke(Clojure.read(":port"), Clojure.read("12000"));
I needed the following dependencies: 
implementation(group="org.clojure", name="clojure", version=clojure_version)
    implementation(group="org.clojure", name="spec.alpha", version=spec_version)
    implementation(group="org.clojure", name="core.specs.alpha", version=core_specs_version)
	implementation(group="nrepl", name="nrepl", version=nrepl_version)
#2019-07-1919:02phreedNote that I needed both core.specs.alpha and spec.alpha.#2019-08-1700:50cflemingI’d like to be able to send arbitrary messages back from my nREPL server process to the client. Any suggestions for how to handle this?#2019-08-1700:51cflemingCurrently the way this works in Cursive is that for a particular evaluation, I register a handler which handles values, out & err, errors etc, and associate the handler with the eval ID. When the eval is done I remove the handler so they don’t hang around forever.#2019-08-1700:53cflemingHowever this doesn’t work very well for some use cases. For example, when working with CLJS when an eval results in a promise it would be nice to be able to send that value back to the client when the promise is fulfilled, but by that time the original evaluation is probably done and the handler will have been cleaned up.#2019-08-1700:54cflemingI don’t want to keep all handlers around forever, but I’m not sure what a good expiry policy would be for them. Keep them around for n seconds? Keep the latest 100 around and expire them in a LRU fashion? I’m not sure.#2019-08-1700:55cflemingThis is also an issue with Clojure if an eval spins up a new thread.#2019-08-1704:51dominicmCider provides middleware for this I think.#2019-08-1706:45bozhidar> Currently the way this works in Cursive is that for a particular evaluation, I register a handler which handles values, out & err, errors etc, and associate the handler with the eval ID. When the eval is done I remove the handler so they don’t hang around forever.#2019-08-1706:50bozhidar@cfleming CIDER operates similarly. I just remove the handlers when a message is :done and fallback to a default handler for responses that come for messages without a removed handler. I’ve been meaning to improve this for ages, but I never got to doing so.#2019-08-1706:50bozhidar> Keep the latest 100 around and expire them in a LRU fashion?#2019-08-1706:50bozhidarI’d probably go with this one, although I doubt you’ll need more than the last 10.#2019-08-1706:54bozhidar> Cider provides middleware for this I think. No, the handlers are purely a client concern. Every client decides themselves how to track responses and react to them - a handler in CIDER is just several lambdas that act on value, err, out, etc for a particular message id.#2019-08-1707:50bozhidar> I’d like to be able to send arbitrary messages back from my nREPL server process to the client. Any suggestions for how to handle this?#2019-08-1707:50bozhidarCan you elaborate on this? Some example would be useful.#2019-08-1707:51bozhidarI assume you want to associate some extra data with the requests and it would be attached to the responses, but I’m not quite certain I got this right.#2019-08-1708:54dominicmMaybe I misunderstood, I thought he was after wrap-out#2019-08-1708:58pezWhat is wrap-out? Sounds like something I've been out looking for...#2019-08-1709:13bozhidar@pez Output redirection middleware https://github.com/clojure-emacs/cider-nrepl/blob/master/src/cider/nrepl/middleware/out.clj#2019-08-1709:14bozhidarIt ensure that output doesn’t end up in the server terminal instead of the user’s REPL/code buffer.#2019-08-1709:15pez> It ensure that output doesn’t end up in the server terminal instead of the user’s REPL/code buffer. So I was out looking for this! 😄#2019-08-1812:34Daniel SlutskyHi All. #2019-10-1406:52cflemingI found a couple of issues about this, but they were either about using very old versions of various things, or about using trampoline with leiningen.#2019-10-1406:53cflemingI’m establishing my server like this: 
`(do
   (-> (File. ~(.getCanonicalPath init-file))
       (.deleteOnExit))
   (try (require 'nrepl.server 'nrepl.config 'nrepl.cmdline)
        (catch Throwable t#
          (println "Error loading nrepl.server:"
                   (or (.getMessage t#) (type t#)))))
   (try
     (let [config# (merge {:host "127.0.0.1"
                           :port 0}
                          nrepl.config/config)
           {:keys [port# bind# handler# transport# greeting#]} (nrepl.cmdline/server-opts config#)
           server# (nrepl.server/start-server
                     :port port#
                     :bind bind#
                     :ack-port ~ack-port
                     :handler handler#
                     :transport-fn transport#
                     :greeting-fn greeting#)
           port# (:port server#)]
       (println "nREPL server started on port" port# "on host 127.0.0.1"))
     (catch Throwable t#
       (println "Error starting server:"
                (or (.getMessage t#) (type t#))))))
#2019-10-1406:54cflemingdeps.edn: 
{:deps    {org.clojure/clojurescript {:mvn/version "1.10.520"}}
 :aliases {:repl {:extra-deps {nrepl/nrepl {:mvn/version "0.6.0"}
                               cider/piggieback {:mvn/version "0.4.2"}}}}}

I’d assumed Cider had an elisp nREPL client, but if it does then I assume it can’t use drawbridge.#2019-10-1509:49dominicmNo. I don't think so.#2019-10-1509:50dominicmI don't think the alternative protocols get much love.#2019-10-1510:33shenI'm not sure what uses drawbridge really#2019-10-1511:21pezThere was an Eclipse extension using it, iirc. Forgot the name of it now...#2019-10-1520:04cflemingCounterClockwise, probably#2019-10-1520:16pezYes, that’s the name. Is anyone using Eclipse for Clojure hacking these days, you think?#2019-10-1521:07bozhidarIt has been dead for years.#2019-10-1521:07bozhidar> I’m not sure what uses drawbridge really#2019-10-1521:08bozhidarMost notably Leiningen. 🙂#2019-10-1521:08bozhidar> Do Cider (and other editors) implement support for nREPL over HTTP using drawbridge?#2019-10-1521:08bozhidar@cfleming To my knowledge no editor does this.#2019-10-1521:10bozhidar> If so, how does that work? I’d assumed Cider had an elisp nREPL client, but if it does then I assume it can’t use drawbridge. Basically you need to send the same requests/process the same responses over HTTP. Drawbridge itself would be transparent to the clients, but the overhead of dealing with HTTP is overkill for most clients I guess. A few users requested support for this in Emacs over the years, but the only real use-case was to debug remote apps, which they can easily do over an ssh tunnel as well.#2019-10-1521:11cflemingThe main use case that has been requested for Cursive is to have a REPL exposed with better auth control.#2019-10-1521:12cflemingI’m actually having problems getting drawbridge to work. When I connect, new-session just hangs. I can get a client and a transport, but I can’t see why that should be the case.#2019-10-1521:14cfleming@bozhidar AFAICT, all lein does to support drawbridge is to (require 'drawbridge.client) when connecting to a URL, is that right?#2019-10-1606:48bozhidarYeah, pretty much it.#2019-10-1606:49bozhidarThis registers the necessary URL handler.#2019-10-1623:56cflemingOk, in that case I just can’t get it to work. I think I’m going to ditch that support for now.#2019-10-1702:58bozhidarFair enough. Sorry for not being able to provide more help with this, but this week is beyond crazy for me.#2019-10-1702:59bozhidarAs usual - please file a ticket, so we can follow-up on this. I assume that whatever the problem is it’s probably something small. Always the hard part of drawbridge was setting it up server-side. 🙂#2019-10-1911:45pezWhere can I find a list of “built-in” pprint vars?#2019-10-1911:47pezFound it. https://github.com/clojure-emacs/cider-nrepl/blob/master/src/cider/nrepl/pprint.clj#2019-10-1911:56pezHowever, if I try to use zpring-pprint I get

zprint dumps the whole database, with schemas and all, retaining reader literals. fipp also dumps the whole database, but “expands” (or whatever the term is) the reader literals. clojure.core/pprint prints the same thing as with no pretty printing. Which is:

Not sure how to categorize it, but if not pretty printing, things do not go crazy.#2019-10-1913:52dpsuttonWild guess. The db implements IAssoc or something but not a print method and the pretty printers walk it trying to be helpful#2019-10-1913:57pezI probably need to do my pretty printing in a static way.#2019-10-1914:00pez> and the pretty printers walk it trying to be helpful It certainly seems to be something like this, because on my work project, evaluating something like 
@(d/transact conn [{:db/doc "Hello world"}])
with pretty printing enabled never finishes and the java process heat up my machine like mad.#2019-10-1914:27dominicmYeah. This is pretty normal with pretty printing.#2019-10-1914:27dominicmComponent is another common one.#2019-10-2021:12pezStupid question time. Is there a chance I can get the results from eval as EDN if I use the EDN transport?#2019-10-2105:39bozhidar@pez Right now this can’t be done, but we’ve discussed it at some point with @shen. As this would result in changing more than the data encoding we’ve decided to first just return exactly the same data and consider a “richer” format down the road.#2019-10-2105:40bozhidarHow do you plan to handle raw EDN on the client, btw? You might end up having to deal with unknown data readers (for instance)?#2019-10-2107:55shenThis is the rich printing functionality from unrepl?#2019-10-2108:22pez> How do you plan to handle raw EDN on the client, btw? You might end up having to deal with unknown data readers (for instance)? To avoid burning up my computer just because I have pprint enabled when I evaluate a datomic transaction, I am moving the pprint stuff client side in Calva. I then have the problem that I need to parse the result and those datomic value-symbols do not parse. I solve it by just printing it w/o prettifying in the catch clause. But if I could get the result that I today get as EDN, then maybe I can get a prettifyer to work on it. I haven't tested that yet, because I don't know how to test it. So wanted to check if I could even dream about having EDN in, before I go about figuring out the next step.#2019-10-2108:23dominicmSeems like you could write a new server-side pretty printer?#2019-10-2108:24pezAs for unkown data readers. We already have that situation with the non-pretty results, right? They come back as literals. Only if I let nrepl pretty-print it they get unpacked.#2019-10-2108:25pezYeah, I should test with providing a server side pretty printer too. Last I was alive and taked with @bozhidar I think we discussed: 1/ unbundling printing in: * generic preemptible walking (can only done server-side) * layout (client or server) 2/ using unlikely char sequences (unicode provate or ANSI escape code) to intersperse “browsing affordances” in the middle of printed output (for quick regex-powered rendering)#2019-10-2109:54shenNot sure there has been much more talk? think @bozhidar just talked to me about some of the ideas that's been floating around#2019-10-2109:55bozhidarYeah, nothing much has happened. (go
    (while true
      (println "hello")
      (Thread/sleep 1000)))
#2019-10-2618:30dominicmI don't think so, it's in another thread now.#2019-10-2619:01thheller@pez there is no way to interrupt that no. it would also occupy an entire thread from the thread pool so this must be avoided at all cost 😛#2019-10-2619:03dominicmI wonder if you can poke at that thread pool,#2019-10-2619:05thhellerits a var in some namespace#2019-10-2619:05pezHow about if it is in ClojureScript? I’m just curious.#2019-10-2619:06thhellerCLJS doesn't have Thread/sleep?#2019-10-2619:06pezNo, but it has similar constructs, no? So you can evaluate something and get “done” back and it would keep running.#2019-10-2619:06thhellerbut no you can't interrupt an infinite loop in JS. the browser will kill it eventually together with your page though 😉#2019-10-2619:07thhellerno, you can't block in JS#2019-10-2619:07dominicmThere's no sleep function at least#2019-10-2619:07thhellerif you just keep doing work nothing else will ever happen and your browser/node will lock up#2019-10-2619:08dominicmThere are blocking functions (e.g. Nodejs)#2019-10-2619:10thhellerok yes. there are ways to block, but it is a terrible idea to do that 😛#2019-10-2619:11thhellerits ok if that is the only thing your program is supposed to be doing anyways#2019-10-2619:25pezSo in a ClojureScript REPL, using nREPL, is it possible to interrupt this? 
((fn foo []
   (println "hello")
   (js/setTimeout foo 1000)))
#2019-10-2619:27thhellerno#2019-10-2619:27pezOr does that fall under this? > no you can’t interrupt an infinite loop in JS#2019-10-2619:28thhellerwell it will have returned a number#2019-10-2619:28thhelleryou can use that number to call (js/clearTimeout num)#2019-10-2619:29pezYeah, but that’s cheating. 😃#2019-10-2619:29thhellerbut that only works if you hit it before the first repeat 😉#2019-10-2619:29thhellerbut no that will forever keep doing its thing. no way to stop it. at least it will allow the browser to do other stuff while waiting for the timeout 😛#2019-10-2619:29pezIndeed. It keeps printing here.#2019-10-2619:31thhelleryou can override what setTimeout does but that gets into really messy territory 😛#2019-10-2619:31pezAt least in a browser app I can reload the page.#2019-10-2619:33pezI’m asking this because we’re implementing the interrupt op in Calva.#2019-10-2619:33dominicmSeems like there'd be some value in a debugging api provided by browsers that had these registries available.#2019-10-2619:33thhellerinterrupt doesn't even work reliably in clojure/JVM#2019-10-2619:34pezAnd we can now stop trying to figure out how these constructs would be interrupted. 😃#2019-10-2808:28shenThere's been some recent work on interrupts (in JVM): https://github.com/nrepl/nrepl/pull/153#2019-10-2808:28shenand https://github.com/nrepl/nrepl/pull/163#2019-10-2808:35bozhidarFYI - I’ve ported the nREPL ops docs generation to cider-nrepl https://docs.cider.mx/cider-nrepl/nrepl-api/ops.html#2019-10-2808:36bozhidarProbably at some point we’ll have to make this reusable, so any middleware can use it, but at least I’ve solved the most pressing and long-standing issue of generating some API docs for cider-nrepl itself.#2019-10-2808:42pezThat is awesome, @bozhidar!!!#2019-10-2808:42shenI can't remember if we can interrupt a thread that was spawned by the main session thread, but if if we are using a shared thread pool to run a fn, then without some knowledge of the threadpool, not sure how we can just interrupt something running in it?#2019-10-2808:42shen(sorry, interlacing the conversation)#2019-10-2808:43pez¯\(ツ)/¯#2019-10-2808:45bozhidar@shen If we can do this, that’d be great, but I’m not sure how we can get any insight as to where exactly some thread spawned from the main thread ended up.#2019-10-2808:45bozhidarI never really looked into this, though. I just assumed it probably wasn’t feasible (or it was pretty hard) if Chas didn’t implement it initially.#2019-10-2808:46shenDo you know about the interrupting non-pooled thread part?#2019-10-2808:49shenhttps://github.com/nrepl/nrepl/blob/f189b4c07579f8b6752f2e385e52c3680c2e1d60/src/clojure/nrepl/middleware/session.clj#L204-L207 <- how we make non-pooled threads#2019-10-2813:03bozhidar@shen What about it exactly? I don’t think we have any provisions for interrupting anything besides the session thread.#2019-10-2813:04bozhidarI think that even to be able to track the relationship between parent and child threads we need some explicit tracking with a ThreadGroup or something similar.#2019-10-2813:05bozhidarIf I recall correctly Java threads don’t keep any info about the their children/parent threads.#2019-10-2813:07dominicmI've never heard of that happening.#2019-10-2813:14shenOk. I wasn't sure if we had some way of doing that#2019-10-2813:14shensounds like a no then#2019-10-2813:14shenthe code quoted just creates the main session thread, right?#2019-10-3007:38pezBefore I file an issue, I want to check if I’m misunderstanding something. When creating a fresh re-frame app with 10x, using the Leiningen template I get this events.cljs file: 
(ns fresh-10x.events
  (:require
   [re-frame.core :as re-frame]
   [fresh-10x.db :as db]
   [day8.re-frame.tracing :refer-macros [fn-traced defn-traced]]
   ))

(re-frame/reg-event-db
 ::initialize-db
 (fn-traced [_ _]
   db/default-db))

(re-frame/reg-event-db
 ::set-active-panel
 (fn-traced [db [_ active-panel]]
   (assoc db :active-panel active-panel)))
Requesting info on this namespace (`fresh-10x.events`) gives back a response with an empty file entry (an empty array, as it happens). But if I add (def foo 42) to the file, then the info op resolves the file path. What gives?#2019-10-3009:40bozhidar> the code quoted just creates the main session thread, right?#2019-10-3009:40bozhidar@shen Yes.#2019-10-3109:06pezShould I file an issue with the info mystery I mentioned above?#2019-10-3109:37bozhidar@pez Definitely.#2019-10-3109:49pezCool. Just take a look at .#2019-11-0108:28pez@bozhidar, I’ve gotten that far. 😄 I should have been clearer… What I’d like to setup is so that I can run my orchard.info.clj end-to-end, from the editor and explore what happens down there in info.clj. If that’s possible.#2019-11-0109:41bozhidar@pez I just develop it like any other library and test the changes in the REPL, while hacking on something. Alternatively you can rebuild cider-nrepl with the snapshot of orchard and test your changes end-to-end in this manner.#2019-11-0109:46pezYeah, I’ll just have to figure out why my lein install of cider-nrepl isn’t used. I’m doing it the “just another library way” now. Added this test: https://github.com/PEZ/orchard/commit/754ae065cac18e97db80164a261e8e44f76792b9 If you have feedback to an orchard noob, please don’t hesitate. 😃#2019-11-0112:10pezI have isolated the problem down to that meta/ns-meta relies on (ns-publics) to give it something to get a var out of, and then run (var-meta) on that to get the file path. So then if the namespace doesn’t have any publics we get get a nil file entry. A brute fix is this 
(defn ns-meta
  [ns]
  (when ns
    (merge
     (meta ns)
     {:ns (ns-name ns)
      :name (ns-name ns)
      :file (or (-> (ns-publics ns)
                    first
                    second
                    var-meta
                    :file)
                (->
                 (ns/canonical-source ns)
                 .getPath))
      :line 1})))
But it feels like there should be something more elegant/safe… What do you guys think?#2019-11-0913:10pezIs there a reason why zprint dependencies are not provided directly with cider-nrepl as they are with puget and fipp?#2019-11-0920:01dominicmPuget and fipp are grandfathered in. They'd be removed if it wouldn't break the backwards compatibility. The goal is to make cider lighter.#2019-11-0920:11pezOki. Not sending the PR then. 😎#2019-11-0922:41pezI am having problems giving zprint this option map over nREPL: {:record {:to-string? true}}, because I don’t seem to be able to bencode booleans to anything else but 0/1, and zprint checks that it is a boolean… Is it possible to send a boolean proper over bencode? Or is there some other way I can achieve this? Feels like a problem I should have encountered before, but I haven’t…#2019-11-1019:37shenI wonder if we should read-string the value?#2019-11-1019:39shenIt feels quite limiting to only be able to use what can survive the bencode conversion to and fro#2019-11-1019:43shenGoogling ":nrepl.middleware.print/options" doesn't yield that many results, so I'm guessing this doesn't get used much other than to pass {:right-margin 70} or similar around#2019-11-1110:20pezYeah, it is a bit surprising that it took me so long to run in to this limitation. #2019-12-1917:33Pavel Klavík
(defn drawbridge-handler
  []
  (-> (drawbridge/ring-handler)
      util/wrap-log-request-and-response
      (defaults/wrap-defaults (assoc-in defaults/api-defaults [:params :nested] true))
      session/wrap-session))

Possibly the  root cause of the slowness is the issue described here: https://github.com/nrepl/drawbridge/issues/10#2020-03-1118:09Joe CorneliI'm also having trouble connecting Drawbridge -> Heroku on HTTPS.#2020-03-1118:09Joe Cornelihttps://github.com/nrepl/drawbridge/issues/43#2020-03-2220:22djblueI have a quick question about the nrepl protocol. Is there a concept of a langauge when connected to a nrepl server? Whenever I see nrepl implemented for Clojurescript, it's always like a side channel thing that takes over the session that the client has to side effect. The client can't easily ask what language it's connected to over nrepl.#2020-03-2220:25djblueI ask this because in implementing a native clojurescript nrepl server, I can't seem to find any clients (vim-fireplace, calva, etc.) that work out of the box, they all assume clojure and have specific hacks for piggieback, figwheel and shadow-cljs.#2020-03-2220:50bozhidar> I have a quick question about the nrepl protocol. Is there a concept of a langauge when connected to a nrepl server? #2020-03-2220:50bozhidarCurrently there’s nothing like this, but it can easily be added to the session metadata (for instance).#2020-03-2220:51bozhidar> Whenever I see nrepl implemented for Clojurescript, it’s always like a side channel thing that takes over the session that the client has to side effect. The client can’t easily ask what language it’s connected to over nrepl.#2020-03-2220:52bozhidarTo my knowledge there are no ClojureScript implementation of nREPL, so I’m a bit puzzled as to what you’re referring to. Piggieback simply changes a regular evaluation session to use the ClojureScript compiler, but it’s still written in Clojure. Therefore the need for clients to look for certain bindings in the session and determine whether it’s Clojure or ClojureScript session.#2020-03-2220:53bozhidarIf we had native ClojureScript servers the clients would know they connected to one and there wouldn’t really be a need to query about the language, although I understand this might be useful in certain cases.#2020-03-2221:00djblueHow do they distinguish clojure from clojurescript from the nrepl protocol?#2020-03-2220:54bozhidarObviously with a native ClojureScript server you won’t be able to host both Clojure and ClojureScript REPLs in the same server, but I doubt that’s an issue for most people .#2020-03-2220:55bozhidar> I ask this because in implementing a native clojurescript nrepl server, I can’t seem to find any clients (vim-fireplace, calva, etc.) that work out of the box, they all assume clojure and have specific hacks for piggieback, figwheel and shadow-cljs.
Because so far there hasn’t been an alternative. 🙂 Are you working on a native ClojureScript implementation?#2020-03-2220:56djblueThanks for the quick and in-depth response @bozhidar!#2020-03-2220:58djblueI started working on an nrepl server prototype that ran on lumo/nodejs last year and ran into these issues. I got busy with some other stuff but was inspired by https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dZ4xczP5zDI to start looking into it again.#2020-03-2220:59djblueIt's a very rough prototype https://github.com/djblue/nrepl-cljs#2020-03-2221:27bozhidarGlad to hear this!#2020-03-2221:29bozhidarI’m hear to help if you need me. Btw, on a similar note - @borkdude just started to work on nREPL for babashka!#2020-03-2221:30borkdudecool, I'll take a look at nrepl-cljs as reference#2020-03-2221:41djblueThe code is pretty rough 😆#2020-03-2221:41djblueThe best part is probably https://github.com/djblue/nrepl-cljs/blob/master/src/nrepl/bencode.cljs#2020-03-2221:42borkdudeno worries 😉#2020-03-2221:43djblueAlthough setting up a proxy https://github.com/djblue/nrepl-cljs/blob/master/src/nrepl/proxy.cljs and logging message with an existing implementation is really helpful :thumbsup:#2020-03-2221:46djblueIt would be really cool if you made the nrepl_server.clj a cljc file and made the transport platform specific!#2020-03-2221:48borkdudeThe primary goal is to make it work for babashka. What's the goal of nrepl-cljs?#2020-03-2221:48djblueI wanted to get it working with lumo or any other nodejs based runtime#2020-03-2221:49djblueAlso found https://github.com/borkdude/nrepl-server#reverse-engineering-the-nrepl-protocol, so it seems we have done very similar things 😆#2020-03-2221:50djblueBasically I want people to be able to dev clojurescript without the jvm#2020-03-2221:51borkdudeWhat nREPL clients don't use the JVM?#2020-03-2221:52djblueVim-fireplace, calva, and other editors which act as clients don't require a jvm right?#2020-03-2221:53djblueThey usually just connect to the server via something like python or typescript based on the editor#2020-03-2221:53borkduderight#2020-03-2221:53borkdudeI just started working on this today#2020-03-2221:57djblueI don't think you will run into as many problems as I did because babashka is more clojure than clojurescript.#2020-03-2308:32bozhidarThere are also OCaml, Python and Ruby clients for nREPL, btw. Probably some others as well, I never tried to keep track of all of them.#2020-03-2222:21borkdude@bozhidar I'm trying to use nrepl/bencode with babashka which is compiled with GraalVM. GraalVM doesn't like this part:
https://github.com/nrepl/bencode/blob/04287269237788811ee4726d5a51db72d5d600d1/src/bencode/core.clj#L317
Since 1.9 Clojure has a bytes? predicate:

(defn bytes?
  "Return true if x is a byte array"
  {:added "1.9"}
  [x] (if (nil? x)
        false
        (-> x class .getComponentType (= Byte/TYPE))))

Maybe we could use that in bencode?#2020-03-2222:21borkdudeIf bencode should still support clojure 1.8 we could just inline that expression#2020-03-2222:23borkdudefor now I'm just going to copy the bencode code and modify it for babashka#2020-03-2306:35pezA CLJS nREPL server? I must pinch my arm.#2020-03-2315:31djblueFor now I'm targeting node/lumo but eventually any javascript runtime with tcp should work. I got calva working with nrepl-cljs by pretending it was nashhorn.#2020-03-2315:33djblueI guess calva checks for a specific string before it trusts its actually a cljs nrepl server.#2020-03-2315:33djblue"To quit, type: :cljs/quit"#2020-03-2315:34pezThat's configurable, but yes, by default it waits for that string before it considers the connection complete.#2020-03-2315:36pezWe will need to modify Calva a bit to support this in a smooth way. And I am eager to do those modifications! 😃#2020-03-2315:43djblueI already pulled down the calva repo for debugging through the first problem. I'm down to pull down any test branches to see how it works :thumbsup:#2020-03-2315:47pezToday Calva makes quite a big assumption that it is connectiong to a CLJ server. To create a sensible Ux we will need to remove that assumption. Which I think might be a pretty heavy rewrite. But also, it isn't all that much code, so should be within reach.#2020-03-2316:39pezHere's a branch where I have started adding a generic project type. Still CLJ and all that, but anyway. I can connect smoothly to babashka's nrepl server at least. https://github.com/BetterThanTomorrow/calva/tree/wip/generic-project-type#2020-03-2319:14pezThinking about it.... Calva will think it is a CLJ repl, but if the files are named as .cljc it would work.#2020-03-2306:39pezAs for querying the language from the server, as @bozhidar says, there hasn't been a need for that yet. 😃 But even so, Calva can check the project files and ask the user.#2020-03-2306:40pez(If I understand the question correctly.)#2020-03-2308:27bozhidar@borkdude Feel free to also directly update the library. It can very well be a different library then.#2020-03-2409:58bozhidarAs long as it serves the purpose the API doesn’t matter that much.#2020-03-2410:48borkdudeI welcome anyone who is interested in the nREPL support for babashka to contribute. Thanks for spotting it!#2020-03-3114:04KevinHi! I want to create a UI that modifies Clojure functions. Basically in the UI there should be a text editor containing a specific function's (or defmethod) body. On save that function body should change in the selected project.

 Is NREPL the correct tool for this? I was thinking of having an NREPL start in the Clojure application, and the UI would communicate through that. Is that a viable option or would I have to use a different method?#2020-03-3114:05KevinI don't think NREPL can actually change the code in the file. But maybe it can help with finding function locations and such?#2020-03-3114:06KevinAny advice would be appreciated simple_smile#2020-04-0108:14bozhidarWell, you can do pretty much everything with a REPL, so while it’s main purpose is to eval code, there’s no limit to what that code can do. It’d be pretty easy to figure out where something is defined simply by checking it’s metadata.#2020-04-0108:19KevinOh wow. I didn't even know function definitions have meta data. (well I should've, since I do use ^:private quite a bit)#2020-04-0108:21KevinSo if I were to attach to an NREPL in a specific project, I could check the metadata like you said#2020-04-0108:21KevinThank you, Clojure is full of surprises for me 🙂#2020-03-3114:11KevinWell, this might answer my question on defmethods at least: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/52861401/dynamically-get-the-source-strings-of-clojure-multimethod-implementation#2020-04-0107:23vinaiHello everyone. Connecting to nREPL at https:/user:

I can see there is plenty of HTTP traffic to /repl all the time while it hangs…

When I start the uberjar locally and try to connect with drawbridge all works fine.

Can you think of something you’ve changed in the app recently that might be related?#2020-04-0108:12bozhidarAs for the debugging - I’m not sure what’s the best approach, but it’d simple enough to add some logging to drawbridge, build a local package and test with it.#2020-04-0108:49vinaiThank you. There where no changes on the app, but maybe Heroku made some changes - even though that is kind of unlikely, too. I guess I’ll try to build a local package with logging…#2020-04-1211:38pezIf I place a breakpoint on line 8 here: https://github.com/PEZ/clojurecism/blob/master/meetup/src/meetup.clj#L8 things lock up when I evaluate something that should hit it.#2020-04-1214:00bozhidar@pez Seems like a pretty ordinary function to me. Do you want me to test it in CIDER?#2020-04-1214:32pezThat’s what I did. #2020-04-1214:38pezCalva is bug compatible. 😃#2020-04-1215:11pezShould I file this as an issue?#2020-04-1215:14bozhidar@pez Yep, you should.#2020-04-1215:15bozhidarActually, on second thought I think the problem is pretty simple. I assume you don’t set any print lenth limit, but (range) is infinite and and when you try to realize it in the debugger nothing good can come out of this.#2020-04-1215:16bozhidarI’m wondering if it doesn’t make sense to add some special handling for range and other forms like it that we know are going to cause a lockup without some additional configuration.#2020-04-1215:23pezAh, I see. The thing is that the problem seemed a bit intermittent , so I never suspected the range thing, which we have discussed recently somewhere.#2020-04-1215:25pezMaybe the default should be that the implementing side sets some non-locking print length?#2020-04-1215:31bozhidarWell, that’s certainly an option, although I think it’s better for editor clients to set some default, as this is more visible to the end users. Otherwise they might wonder where some limit is coming from.#2020-04-1215:31bozhidar> The thing is that the problem seemed a bit intermittent#2020-04-1215:32bozhidarWhat happens when you step over it and it doesn’t blow up? Without some print limit I can’t expect how this can work in some cases. 🙂#2020-04-1215:37pezWith implementing side, I meant editor clients. 😃#2020-04-1215:38bozhidar😄#2020-04-1215:39bozhidarCIDER used to have separate print options configs for regular evaluation and for the debugger but at some point we folded those together .#2020-04-1215:39bozhidar
(defcustom cider-print-options nil
  "A map of options that will be passed to `cider-print-fn'.
Here's an example for `pprint':

  '((\"length\" 50) (\"right-margin\" 70))"
  :type 'list
  :group 'cider
  :package-version '(cider . "0.21.0"))
#2020-04-1215:39bozhidarYou can add something like this.#2020-04-1215:40bozhidarFunny enough, when those options had defaults people were complaining there were defaults, and when we removed them - people were complaining there were no defaults. 😄#2020-04-1215:42pezI have had many moments like that with Calva!#2020-04-1215:43pezBut generally, Calva comes with a lot of defaults, so people are more used to it there. 😃#2020-04-1215:44pezThe intermittent thing might have been my testing. Probably was my testing. There were a lot of branches and versions involved... I easily get confused.#2020-04-1215:47pez@brandon.ringe maybe we should consider debug defaults like ^ that ^? I might not be the only one not realizing the implications of attempting to realize and infinite sequence. 😃#2020-04-1220:26bringeYeah, or even a default that is used everywhere, like Bozhidar said. This is related to the large result set issue I think. So a fix there could fix the debug issue perhaps#2020-04-1220:27bringeI think I saw this same issue being discussed elsewhere just the other day, in this slack workspace, but I don't remember where.#2020-04-1220:27bringeRelated to infinite sequences and print length#2020-04-1220:27pezSame here. I know we discussed it somewhere, but where... a slack syndrome.#2020-04-1220:29pezBut it makes sense to me to have a default of infinite generally, but for debug, something finite, and to have settings where both can be changed by the user.#2020-04-1220:30bringeYeah, more settings with reasonable defaults is usually better, imo#2020-04-1220:30pezLess settings is my usual goto. 😃#2020-04-1220:31pezBut this does come to mind. https://youtu.be/QHZ48AE3TOI#2020-04-3008:58shen@bozhidar: thoughts on using more modern dev-time tooling for nREPL?#2020-04-3008:59shenI'm thinking of kaocha in particular#2020-04-3009:00shenas long as we have zero runtime deps, and runtime compatibility back to Clojure 1.7, that should be fine right?#2020-04-3010:59bozhidar@shen Yeah, totally!#2020-04-3011:00bozhidarDev dependencies are not really an issue - we have to be careful only on the runtime side.#2020-04-3011:01shenok. it only works with clojure 1.9+, but for the CI matrix, we should still be able to use lein run for older versions#2020-04-3011:32bozhidarFine by me.#2020-04-3011:02shenso, got most of the dynamic middleware thing working. just trying to figure out dependencies between the modules.#2020-04-3011:04shene.g. sideloader depends on session, and both sits downstream from the dynamic loader (which is not really a middleware), so need to think of a clean way for it to have access to those capabilities without having everything entwined#2020-04-3011:33bozhidarLooking forward to see what you’ve come up with!#2020-04-3011:39shenquite excited. this should allow cider-connect to do almost as much as cider-jack-in#2020-04-3012:02bozhidarThat’s the dream!#2020-05-0115:58shenhttps://github.com/nrepl/nrepl/pull/185 <- Draft PR for the dynamic-loader. This needs some finishing, but I think I've got this approach to work.#2020-05-0115:58shenWould really like to get some comments/suggestions before I go further#2020-05-0116:01pezThat sounds absolutely wonderful, @shen!#2020-05-0116:03shenthanks! been thinking about this on and off for a while now. Finally took the plunge to actually get it to work#2020-05-0309:36Eugenhi, I'm new to clojure from Java and I would like to know how to embed nrepl in a production java app and what gui tools can I use to connect to it. what options are there for security (authentication) ?#2020-05-0320:19shenthe default transports are all socket based. What people typically do is to allow connection from local only, without security, then reply on SSH to provide security#2020-05-0320:20shenthere is https://github.com/nrepl/drawbridge, which gives access over https. don't think there's any built in security, but you are free to add your own there.#2020-05-0320:24shenin term of GUI tools, the best bet are the ones built into the major clojure dev tools, e.g. Cursive for IntelliJ or Calva for VSCode#2020-05-0320:24shenI'm sure standalone tools exist, but that's not a common way to use nREPL, so doubt they are too well developed#2020-05-0320:24shenditto for brower based clients#2020-05-0320:26shenHere's a list of clients: https://nrepl.org/nrepl/0.7.0/usage/clients.html#2020-05-0320:26shennot all of them are in active development, and some are very dead though#2020-05-0320:26shenbut compatibility should still be good#2020-05-0409:21Eugenthanks, it's very helpful#2020-05-0409:21EugenI did manage to do what I was aiming for https://github.com/netdava/ofbiz-clojure-repl#2020-05-0409:21EugenI've gone with basic socket based nRepl#2020-05-0409:22Eugenit can be started / stopped at will#2020-05-0409:22Eugenauthentication is an issue - since there are no OOTB options out there#2020-05-0409:24EugenI think drawbridh over websocket + Oauth2 / OpenID connect would be nice at some point#2020-05-0309:38EugenI'm working on adopting clojure inside some projects and this is something that I would like to experiment with:

That said, my applications don’t run through leiningen, so it would still be beneficial to me if either leiningen or nREPL allows ‘forcing’ an init-ns. I amended the issue with this information.#2020-05-0610:16shenah right. that makes sense.#2020-05-0610:18shenwill respond in the gh issue#2020-05-0611:45shenjust want to check: do you have a workaround right now?#2020-05-0611:45shenrelease cycle for nrepl/lein etc. is not that fast#2020-05-0613:14Lennart Buityeah, just swapping ns manually. send-> {:op "eval" :code "(+ 1 2)" :my-thing/silent? true}
<-recv {:value "3" :my-thing/silent? true}

My use case is that I want to eval an entire namespace, but I don't want to flood the REPL output with the names of every var that gets defined. Instead, I'd like to just show something like "Loading my.awesome.ns…".

I know I can do it by keeping track of the IDs of the ops I'm sending, but I'm just wondering whether there's something simpler I could do.#2020-05-1411:35flowthingThe documentation suggests that :id is the only datum that's the same in the request and the response, so I think I'll just use that.#2020-05-1508:02shenhmm.. what client you are using?#2020-05-1508:03shenas bozhidar said, nothing built in, and this is probably way easier to do on the client side than server#2020-05-1508:05flowthingI'm building my own:

This is something that CIDER injects when starting up. If you update CIDER it will update the version it injects to the latest if you’re not already there. These warnings are not an issue. Reflection warnings let you find slow spots in your code but this is fooling that exists only at dev time#2020-06-0723:24manas_marthiI am returning to clojure after a long time.
